Option A. Short Stature: Correct statement. Short stature is a common clinical feature of Noonan Syndrome. Affected individuals typically have growth issues and remain shorter than average.

 

Option B. Webbed Neck: Correct statement. Webbed neck (pterygium colli) is a distinctive physical characteristic of Noonan Syndrome. This feature involves excess skin on the neck creating a webbed appearance similar to what is seen in Turner Syndrome.

 

Option C. Low Posterior Hairline: Correct statement. A low posterior hairline is another typical physical feature of Noonan Syndrome. This refers to hair growth that extends unusually low on the back of the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan Syndrome presents with distinctive physical features including short stature, webbed neck, and low posterior hairline, but has a normal karyotype, distinguishing it from chromosomal disorders like Turner Syndrome which may present with similar physical characteristics but show chromosomal abnormalities on karyotype analysis.

questions.text: What is an absolute contraindication for attempting a vaginal birth after a previous Cesarean section? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical CS in first pregnancy

 

Previous classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication for vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). Classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment, which has a significantly higher risk of rupture (4-9%) compared to the lower segment transverse incision (0.2-1.5%). The rupture of a classical scar can occur both during pregnancy and labor, making it unpredictable and potentially catastrophic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregnancy Induced Hypertension: Incorrect. While pregnancy-induced hypertension is a complication that requires careful monitoring, it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The decision would depend on the severity of hypertension, presence of other complications, and overall maternal and fetal wellbeing.

 

Option C. Grade 1 Placenta Praevia: Incorrect. Grade 1 placenta previa (low-lying placenta) may increase the risk during vaginal delivery, but it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The management would depend on the exact location of the placenta in relation to the cervical os and previous uterine scar.

 

Option D. Mild Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD): Incorrect. Mild CPD may pose challenges for vaginal delivery, but it is not an absolute contraindication for VBAC. The decision would depend on careful assessment of the maternal pelvis, fetal size, and progression of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous classical cesarean section carries a significantly higher risk of uterine rupture (4-9%) compared to lower segment transverse incision (0.2-1.5%), making it an absolute contraindication for attempting vaginal birth after cesarean delivery due to the unpredictable nature of rupture that can occur during both pregnancy and labor.

questions.text: What is the mean pH of the vagina during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 

 

The pH of the vagina during pregnancy is 3.5-4. During pregnancy, there is increased estrogen level which leads to increased glycogen content in the vaginal epithelium. This glycogen is converted to lactic acid by the action of Lactobacilli, resulting in an acidic vaginal environment. The acidic pH of the vagina serves as a protective mechanism against potential pathogens during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5: This is incorrect. A pH of 5 does not represent the vaginal pH during pregnancy. A pH of 5.6 is actually seen in newborns due to the influence of maternal estrogen, not during pregnancy itself.

 

Option C. 6: This is incorrect. A pH of 6-8 represents the vaginal pH in children before puberty. This alkaline pH is due to the lack of estrogen influence and consequently lower glycogen content and reduced Lactobacilli activity.

 

Option D. 7: This is incorrect. A pH of 7 (neutral) is associated with the vagina during menopause. At this stage, estrogen levels decline significantly, resulting in reduced glycogen content, decreased Lactobacilli, and consequently a higher (more alkaline) vaginal pH.

 

Vaginal pH Across Life Stages

 

The vaginal pH varies throughout different life stages due to changing estrogen levels:

 

  • Newborn: 5.6 (due to maternal estrogen)
  • Children: 6-8 (alkaline pH)
  • Puberty: 4
  • Pregnancy: 3.5-4
  • Reproductive age: 3.5-4.5
  • Menopause: 7

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnancy is associated with a highly acidic vaginal pH of 3.5-4 due to elevated estrogen levels that increase glycogen content in vaginal epithelial cells, which is then metabolized by Lactobacilli to produce lactic acid, creating a protective environment against potential infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of physiological vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyclical

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is characteristically cyclical in nature. Normal vaginal discharge varies throughout the menstrual cycle due to hormonal changes. The discharge increases during specific times such as around ovulation (due to peak rise of estrogen increasing secretory activity of cervical glands) and premenstrually (due to pelvic congestion and increased mucus secretion from hypertrophied endometrial glands). This cyclical pattern is a normal physiological response to hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foul smelling: This is incorrect. Normal physiological vaginal discharge is not foul smelling. Foul odor is typically associated with pathological conditions such as bacterial vaginosis which produces a fishy odor (positive whiff test with KOH) or trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Dirty white in color: This is incorrect. Normal physiological vaginal discharge is described as colorless or white, not dirty white. Dirty white or gray-white discharge is more characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Adherent to the vaginal wall: This is incorrect. While normal discharge may coat the vaginal walls, discharge that is specifically described as "adherent to the vaginal wall" is a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis (homogenous white discharge that coats the vaginal walls), not physiological discharge.

 

Characteristics of Normal Vaginal Discharge

 

Normal physiological vaginal discharge is:

 

  • Colorless/white
  • Non-odorous
  • pH around 4.0 in reproductive age
  • Cyclical in nature related to menstrual cycle phases
  • Contains secretions from vulvar glands, vaginal glands, vaginal transudate and secretions from the cervix, endometrium and fallopian tubes
  • Contains normal flora including Lactobacilli, Streptococci, Staphylococci
  • Shows desquamated epithelial cells, WBCs and Lactobacilli on microscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge has a distinct cyclical pattern throughout the menstrual cycle, with increased secretion during ovulation and premenstrual periods, reflecting the normal hormonal fluctuations of the reproductive system.

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the most appropriate method for the provisional diagnosis of Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from pustular lesions. Group A streptococci characteristically show susceptibility to bacitracin, which serves as a key diagnostic feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. The test is performed by placing a bacitracin disk on a culture plate and observing for a zone of inhibition around the disk, which indicates susceptibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test helps differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). Finding catalase positivity would actually point away from streptococcal infection and toward staphylococcal infection.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is specifically used for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci), not Group A streptococci. S. pneumoniae is highly sensitive to optochin, while other streptococci including Group A are typically resistant.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is used primarily for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile whereas other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not bile soluble. This test would not help confirm a Group A streptococcal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the key diagnostic test for the provisional identification of Group A Streptococcus from clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin being a distinctive characteristic that helps differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: The causative agent for St. Anthony's Fire is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Streptococcus

 

Explanation:

 

St. Anthony's Fire is a historical term that refers to erysipelas, an acute infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics. This condition is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by a bright red, swollen, and indurated skin lesion with a distinct raised border. The condition was named "St. Anthony's Fire" due to the intense burning sensation patients experience and the fiery red appearance of the affected skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Staphylococcus Staphylococcus species, particularly S. aureus, typically cause skin infections such as furuncles, carbuncles, impetigo and wound infections. While they can cause cellulitis, they do not cause the classical erysipelas (St. Anthony's Fire) with its characteristic raised borders and bright red appearance.

 

Option C: Klebsiella Klebsiella is a Gram-negative bacillus of the Enterobacteriaceae family. It is primarily associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and septicemia, particularly in hospitalized patients. It is not associated with erysipelas or St. Anthony's Fire.

 

Option D: Nocardia Nocardia is an aerobic Gram-positive bacterium that causes nocardiosis, which typically presents as a pulmonary infection with possible dissemination to other organs, particularly the brain. It also can cause cutaneous infections, but these typically present as abscesses or mycetomas, not as erysipelas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

St. Anthony's Fire (erysipelas) is a distinctive streptococcal skin infection characterized by sharply demarcated, bright red, indurated lesions with raised borders, caused specifically by Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wool Sorter's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Wool Sorter's disease is NOT a feature of cutaneous anthrax but rather refers to pulmonary anthrax. Wool Sorter's disease is specifically the inhalational form of anthrax that occurs when spores are inhaled, typically among workers handling contaminated wool, hides, or other animal products. It affects the respiratory system, presenting with flu-like symptoms that progress to severe respiratory distress, and has historically had a very high mortality rate (approaching 100% if untreated).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignant pustule - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The characteristic lesion of cutaneous anthrax is known as a "malignant pustule." This term describes the central necrotic, painless lesion that develops at the site of inoculation after spores enter through breaks in the skin.

 

Option B. Hide Porter's disease - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. "Hide Porter's disease" is another name for cutaneous anthrax, named after the occupational risk faced by workers who carried (ported) animal hides, which could be contaminated with anthrax spores.

 

Option C. Black eschar - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The development of a black eschar is the hallmark of cutaneous anthrax. The lesion begins as a painless papule that vesiculates and eventually develops into a characteristic black, necrotic eschar surrounded by non-pitting edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three forms of anthrax have distinct clinical presentations and names: cutaneous anthrax (Hide Porter's disease, malignant pustule) presents with a characteristic painless black eschar; pulmonary anthrax (Wool Sorter's disease) presents with respiratory symptoms; and gastrointestinal anthrax affects the digestive tract after consuming contaminated meat.

choices.text: Aspiration is an important mode of transmission
Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis
Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Legionella pneumonia is true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Aspiration is an important mode of transmission

 

Explanation: 

 

Aspiration is indeed an important mode of transmission for Legionella pneumonia. The text explicitly identifies aspiration as the "predominant mode" of transmission for Legionella. This occurs either via oropharyngeal colonization or directly through drinking contaminated water. This route of infection is more significant than the aerosol transmission that is often associated with Legionnaires' disease outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis - This is incorrect because while urinary antigen testing is a useful and commonly used diagnostic tool for Legionella, it is not described as the gold standard. Culture on specialized media such as Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar is considered the reference method for diagnosis, though it takes longer.

 

Option C. Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever - This is incorrect because these are two distinct clinical entities caused by Legionella. Pontiac fever is described as an "acute, flu-like illness" that is "self-limiting, never develops into pneumonia." In contrast, Legionnaires' disease specifically refers to the pneumonic form of infection characterized by "non-productive cough, dyspnea, chest pain, high fever and diarrhea."

 

Option D. High person-to-person transmission - This is incorrect because the text explicitly states "No man-to-man transmission" for Legionella. The bacteria are acquired solely from environmental sources such as contaminated water systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legionella infection primarily occurs through aspiration of contaminated water, with no person-to-person transmission documented, and presents as either Legionnaires' disease (pneumonia) or Pontiac fever (non-pneumonic flu-like illness) depending on the clinical manifestation.

choices.text: Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

questions.text: All of the following statements about the pathogenesis of Clostridium difficile-associated pseudomembranous enterocolitis are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that "Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B" is false. Both toxins are significant virulence factors in C. difficile infection, but Toxin B is actually considered more potent in causing disease. Both toxins act by glycosylating GTP-binding proteins that regulate the cellular actin cytoskeleton, leading to disruption of the epithelial cell barrier. While Toxin A was historically thought to be the primary toxin, more recent understanding suggests that Toxin B plays the more crucial role in pathogenesis, with some pathogenic strains producing only Toxin B and not Toxin A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exotoxin mediated: This statement is true. C. difficile pathogenesis is indeed exotoxin mediated. The bacteria produce two major exotoxins (Toxin A and Toxin B) that are responsible for the clinical manifestations of disease, including pseudomembrane formation and diarrhea.

 

Option B. Toxin A is an enterotoxin: This statement is true. Toxin A functions primarily as an enterotoxin, affecting intestinal epithelial cells, disrupting tight junctions between cells, and causing fluid secretion in the intestine.

 

Option C. Toxin B is a cytotoxin: This statement is true. Toxin B functions primarily as a cytotoxin, causing direct damage to cells by disrupting the cytoskeleton after glycosylation of GTP-binding proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile causes pseudomembranous colitis through the action of two major exotoxins (Toxin A and Toxin B) that disrupt the cytoskeleton of intestinal epithelial cells, with Toxin B being more potent than Toxin A, contradicting earlier assumptions about their relative importance in pathogenesis.

questions.text: The transfer of genetic information between DNA molecules inside a cell is called: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Transposition

 

Explanation:

 

Transposition is the correct answer because it refers to the movement of DNA segments called transposons ("jumping genes") between different DNA molecules within the same cell. Transposons are discrete segments of DNA that can move from one location to another in a "cut-and-paste" manner between chromosomal and extrachromosomal DNA molecules inside a bacterial cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transformation - This is the transfer of genetic information through free or naked DNA from the environment into a bacterial cell. It involves uptake of external DNA, not transfer between DNA molecules already inside a cell.

 

Option C. Conjugation - This involves the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium (donor or male) to another (recipient or female) through direct physical contact (through a sex pilus). It is a process of transfer between different cells, not between DNA molecules inside the same cell.

 

Option D. Duplication - This refers to the replication of DNA during cell division, where the entire DNA molecule is copied. It does not involve transfer of genetic segments between different DNA molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transposons (mobile genetic elements) facilitate genetic diversity within a cell by moving DNA segments between chromosomal and plasmid DNA. This mechanism of transposition can lead to the acquisition of new characteristics by bacteria, including antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: EBV is associated with all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. MALT lymphoma

 

Explanation:

 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is not associated with MALT (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) lymphoma. EBV has well-established links to several specific malignancies, but MALT lymphoma is not among them. MALT lymphoma is primarily associated with chronic antigenic stimulation, particularly Helicobacter pylori infection in gastric MALT lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma - This statement is correct. EBV has a strong and well-documented association with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, particularly in persons of Chinese origin. This relationship is one of the classic examples of viral oncogenesis.

 

Option B. Hodgkin's lymphoma - This statement is correct. EBV is implicated in the pathogenesis of Hodgkin's lymphoma, especially the mixed-cellularity type. The virus can be detected in Reed-Sternberg cells, which are the hallmark cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis - This statement is correct. Infectious mononucleosis, also known as the "kissing disease," is the classic clinical manifestation of primary EBV infection. It presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and atypical lymphocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EBV plays a significant role in various lymphoproliferative disorders and epithelial cancers including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and infectious mononucleosis, but has no established role in the pathogenesis of MALT lymphoma.

choices.text: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6
The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease
No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Gamma-Release-Assays for the diagnosis of Tuberculosis is correct? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10

 

Explanation:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold (second generation) assay utilizes two specific antigens - ESAT-6 (Early Secretory Antigenic Target-6) and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein-10) for detecting TB infection. These antigens are present in M. tuberculosis complex but absent in BCG vaccine strains and most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making them more specific for TB detection compared to tuberculin skin tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6 This is incorrect because the first generation QuantiFERON-TB assay used tuberculin PPD (purified protein derivative) as the stimulating antigen, not ESAT-6. This made it less specific than the second generation test.

 

Option C: These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease This is incorrect as IGRAs (Interferon-Gamma Release Assays) including QuantiFERON cannot differentiate between latent TB infection and active TB disease. They only detect immune response to TB antigens, indicating exposure or infection.

 

Option D: No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay This is incorrect because some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (such as M. kansasii, M. marinum, and M. szulgai) also possess genes for ESAT-6 and CFP-10, potentially causing false-positive results in the assay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold assay uses ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens to improve specificity over the first generation test, but still cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a heterophile agglutination test? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rose Waaler Test

 

Explanation:


The Rose Waaler Test is not a heterophile agglutination test but rather an autoantibody test used to detect rheumatoid factor. It involves sheep erythrocytes coated with a subagglutinating dose of anti-erythrocyte antibody that are used as antigen in an agglutination test. This test detects autoantibodies (Rheumatoid Factor) that react with the Fc fragment of IgG, making it fundamentally different from heterophile tests that involve cross-reactive antigens between different species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paul-Bunnell Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test. It's used in infectious mononucleosis to detect heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep or horse red blood cells. These antibodies develop in response to EBV infection but cross-react with antigens on these animal erythrocytes.

 

Option B. Weil-Felix Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test. It detects antibodies in rickettsial infections that cross-react with antigens of Proteus vulgaris bacteria, demonstrating shared epitopes between the different species.

 

Option D. Cold Agglutination Test - This IS a heterophile agglutination test used in primary atypical pneumonia (Mycoplasma pneumoniae). It detects antibodies that cause agglutination of human erythrocytes at low temperatures through cross-reactive mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Heterophile agglutination tests involve antibodies produced against one organism that cross-react with antigens of unrelated organisms due to shared epitopes, while the Rose Waaler test detects autoantibodies specific to self-immunoglobulins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the standard agar recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using sensitivity discs? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Mueller Hinton Agar

 

Explanation:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the standard medium recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using the disc diffusion method. It provides consistent results due to its well-defined composition and is specifically designed for this purpose. For fastidious organisms, Mueller Hinton Blood Agar may be used as a modification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PLET Agar - This is not a standard medium for antibiotic susceptibility testing. PLET agar is a selective medium used for isolating specific bacteria Like Bacillus anthracis , not for determining their antibiotic sensitivity patterns.

 

Option B. Castañeda Agar - This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of Brucella species or fungus from blood cultures in a biphasic format (solid and liquid phases in the same container). It is not designed or standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing.

 

Option D. Cetrimide Agar - This is a selective medium used for the isolation and identification of Pseudomonas species, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Its composition is not standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing, and the cetrimide component would interfere with accurate antimicrobial testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the internationally accepted standard medium for antimicrobial susceptibility testing by the disc diffusion method due to its reproducibility, low content of inhibitors, and support of growth for most non-fastidious pathogens of clinical significance.

questions.text: Bile Esculin Agar is used for the identification of: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Enterococcus faecalis

 

Explanation:

 

Bile Esculin Agar is specifically used to differentiate between Enterococcus (group D) from other streptococci. This medium helps detect two important characteristics: the ability to grow in the presence of 40% bile and the ability to hydrolyze esculin to esculetin and glucose. When Enterococcus faecalis grows on this medium, the esculetin combines with ferric ions to produce a black complex (phenolic iron complex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes - This is a Group A Streptococcus that doesn't grow well in the presence of bile and doesn't hydrolyze esculin. It's typically identified using other methods such as beta-hemolysis on blood agar and sensitivity to bacitracin.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae - Pneumococci are identified using other methods, particularly optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests. They don't typically grow on bile-containing media.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus - This is actually another name for Streptococcus pneumoniae (the same organism as in option C), so this is incorrect for the same reasons as option C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile Esculin Agar exploits the unique ability of Group D streptococci (Enterococci) to grow in the presence of bile and hydrolyze esculin, producing a distinctive black color that serves as a valuable diagnostic feature.

questions.text: The ossification center of the clavicle used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Sternal end

 

Explanation:

 

The sternal (medial) end of the clavicle is the ossification center used to confirm bone age for legal consent to marriage. This is a critical ossification center for age estimation in the late teens and early twenties. The secondary center at the medial end of the clavicle appears at around 18 years of age and fuses with the shaft by 21-22 years of age in males (slightly earlier in females).

 

In the context of legal consent to marriage, which typically requires individuals to be at least 18 years for females and 21 years for males in many jurisdictions, the fusion status of the medial end of the clavicle provides valuable evidence for age determination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromial end (Incorrect) The acromial (lateral) end of the clavicle is not commonly used for age determination related to legal consent for marriage as it fuses earlier and doesn't provide relevant age information for the late teens to early twenties.

 

Option C. Shaft (Incorrect) The shaft (body) of the clavicle is the primary ossification center that appears very early (around 5-6 weeks of intrauterine life) and is the first bone to begin ossification. It doesn't provide useful information for age estimation in the context of marriage consent.

 

Option D. Tubercle (Incorrect) The tubercle of the clavicle doesn't have a separate ossification center that would be relevant for age determination in the context of legal consent for marriage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial (sternal) end of the clavicle is a key marker for age estimation between 18-22 years, making it highly valuable for legal age determination in marriage consent cases.

choices.text: Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus
Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation
Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death

questions.text: All of the following statements about the Prinsloo-Gordon artefact are true, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation

 

Explanation:

 

The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact is not a definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation. It is actually a postmortem artifact that can be mistaken for an antemortem injury. This hemorrhagic appearance on the posterior wall of the esophagus is caused by postmortem blood leakage from esophageal venous plexuses and can be confused with signs of trauma if misinterpreted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Described by Prinsloo and Gordon - This statement is CORRECT. The artifact was indeed described by and named after Prinsloo and Gordon, who identified this postmortem phenomenon.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus - This statement is CORRECT. The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact appears as hemorrhage or hemorrhagic-like discoloration on the posterior surface of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death - This statement is CORRECT. The artifact is caused by postmortem leakage of blood from the esophageal venous plexuses, which creates hemorrhagic-appearing areas that can be confused with traumatic injuries.

 

Key Points About Prinsloo-Gordon Artifact

  • Appears as hemorrhagic discoloration on the posterior wall of the esophagus
  • Postmortem phenomenon, not an antemortem injury
  • Can be mistaken for evidence of trauma, particularly neck trauma
  • Important for forensic pathologists to recognize to avoid misinterpretation
  • Does not indicate any specific cause of death

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Prinsloo-Gordon artifact is a postmortem change that may mimic traumatic injury but is not a definitive sign of manual strangulation, highlighting the importance of distinguishing between genuine antemortem injuries and postmortem artifacts in forensic pathology.

choices.text: The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium
It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots
This rule involves the observation of fracture lines
It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously

questions.text: Regarding Puppe's rule, all of the following statements are true EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It is valuable in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously.

 

Explanation: 

 

Puppe's rule states that when two fracture lines intersect each other, the second fracture line never crosses the first one. This principle is crucial for determining the sequence of impacts in cases of multiple skull fractures. The rule specifically helps in establishing chronology - which impact occurred first and which occurred subsequently. For this rule to be applicable, the fractures must have occurred at different times, not simultaneously. This makes option D incorrect because Puppe's rule has no value in cases where multiple bullet injuries occur simultaneously, as the rule is specifically designed to determine sequence over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The rule is associated with bullet injuries to the cranium - This is true. Puppe's rule is applied in cases of cranial fractures, including those caused by bullet injuries, to determine the sequence of impacts.

 

Option B. It is utilized to ascertain the sequence of bullet shots - This is true. The primary purpose of Puppe's rule is to determine the sequence of impacts when multiple fractures are present.

 

Option C. This rule involves the observation of fracture lines - This is true. Puppe's rule is based on observing how fracture lines intersect each other. The second fracture line stops at or is deflected by the first fracture line.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Puppe's rule is a forensic principle that helps determine the sequence of multiple impacts to the skull by analyzing how fracture lines intersect, but it has no value in cases where injuries occur simultaneously.

questions.text: A soft friable extradural hematoma with a honeycomb appearance on autopsy is seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Heat hematoma

 

Explanation:

 

Heat hematoma (also called burn hematoma) shows characteristic features that distinguish it from traumatic extradural hematoma. The defining features include a honeycomb appearance and friable consistency, which are the key diagnostic features. Heat hematoma is recognized as one of the artifacts found in bodies exposed to extreme heat.

 

Comparison with Traumatic EDH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulopathy - While coagulopathy can affect clot formation, it doesn't produce the characteristic honeycomb appearance mentioned in the question. Coagulopathy-related bleeding typically lacks the specific pattern described.

 

Option C. Postmortem; blunt force - Postmortem blunt force wouldn't produce the described honeycomb appearance. Postmortem injuries show no vital reaction, and the blood doesn't typically form organized patterns.

 

Option D. Antemortem; blunt force - Traumatic extradural hematomas due to blunt force have a smooth, jelly-like appearance rather than the honeycomb, friable consistency described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heat hematoma (EDH due to heat) has distinctive characteristics including honeycomb appearance, friable consistency, bilateral presentation, and ability to cross suture lines—all opposite to traumatic EDH features.

choices.text: Lawful under Article 21 of the constitution
Unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution
Lawful under Article 19 of the constitution
Unlawful under Article 19 of the constitution

questions.text: Force feeding of prisoners on hunger strikes is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution

 

Explanation:

 

Force feeding of prisoners on hunger strikes is unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution. The Declaration of Malta specifically addresses hunger strikes and establishes that "respect for individual autonomy restrains physicians from intervening when a valid and informed refusal has been made." Article 21 protects the right to life and personal liberty, which includes the right to refuse medical treatment and preserves bodily autonomy.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A (Lawful under Article 21): This contradicts the principle that Article 21 protects personal liberty, making force feeding against one's will unlawful.
  • Option C (Lawful under Article 19): Article 19 concerns freedom of speech and expression, not bodily autonomy or medical treatment, making this irrelevant to force feeding scenarios.
  • Option D (Unlawful under Article 19): While correctly stating force feeding is unlawful, it incorrectly attributes this to Article 19 rather than Article 21, which is the constitutional provision that actually protects bodily integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Malta provides ethical guidelines for physicians regarding hunger strikers, emphasizing that even when a physician believes intervention would benefit the patient, respect for autonomy must prevail when an informed refusal has been made.

questions.text: All of the following drugs cause miosis, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Phenothiazines

 

Explanation:

 

Miosis refers to pupillary constriction, often described as "pinpoint pupils" in severe cases. Phenothiazines, which include chlorpromazine and other antipsychotic medications, produce mydriasis (pupillary dilation) rather than miosis due to their antagonistic effects on muscarinic cholinergic receptors. This anticholinergic activity blocks the parasympathetic stimulation of the pupillary sphincter muscles, preventing constriction and allowing for pupillary dilation.

 

In toxicological assessment, pupillary examination is critical because it often provides immediate diagnostic clues. The classic triad of opioid toxidrome includes respiratory depression, CNS depression, and miosis. This characteristic pinpoint pupil appearance has high diagnostic value, particularly when unresponsive to light in severe intoxication. Pupillary changes usually persist even in comatose states, making them valuable signs when patients cannot provide history.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Clonidine - Produces miosis through its alpha-2 adrenergic agonist effects. This centrally-acting antihypertensive consistently causes pupillary constriction that can be distinguished from opioid-induced miosis by its responsiveness to light.
  • Option B. Morphine - Causes significant miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system. The miosis is often extreme and unreactive to light stimuli in significant overdose, making it a cardinal sign in opioid toxicity.
  • Option C. Meperidine - As with other opioids, it produces pupillary constriction through mu-receptor activation. This effect is dose-dependent and remains present even when other symptoms fluctuate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pupillary examination provides rapid diagnostic information in toxicology cases - miosis indicates opioids, organophosphates or clonidine, while mydriasis suggests anticholinergics, sympathomimetics, or phenothiazines like chlorpromazine.

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Late distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: In a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus, which part of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Late distal tubule and collecting duct

 

In central diabetes insipidus, there is a deficiency of ADH (vasopressin) secretion from the posterior pituitary. Without ADH, the collecting ducts become relatively impermeable to water. This causes the already dilute fluid entering from the distal tubule to remain hypotonic without the normal water reabsorption that would concentrate it. In diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality can be extremely low (50-100 mOsm/L) due to this lack of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Proximal tubule - Incorrect because proximal tubular fluid remains essentially iso-osmotic with plasma (around 300 mOsm/kg) regardless of ADH status. About 60-70% of filtered water is reabsorbed here through aquaporin-1 channels that function independently of ADH.
  • Option B. Descending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment as water moves out via aquaporin-1 channels into the hypertonic medullary interstitium. ADH status does not significantly affect this segment.
  • Option C. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because while this segment does create hypotonic fluid by actively transporting Na+, K+, and Cl- out of the tubule without water (it's water-impermeable), the tubular fluid becomes even more dilute as it continues through the distal tubule and collecting duct in the absence of ADH.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The late distal tubule and collecting duct display the lowest tubular fluid osmolality in central diabetes insipidus because these segments, which normally concentrate urine under ADH influence, remain impermeable to water without ADH, allowing maximally dilute fluid to be excreted.

choices.text: Rapid filling of the left ventricle

questions.text: The dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve is caused by?  (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Closing of the aortic valve

 

Explanation: 

 

The dicrotic notch is a small oscillation or wave that appears in the falling phase of the aortic pressure curve during the cardiac cycle. This notch is specifically caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shut. The dicrotic notch occurs at the end of ventricular systole when the aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, causing the aortic valve to close. This closure creates a brief backward movement of blood and subsequent rebound, generating the characteristic notch in the aortic pressure tracing.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch.
  • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch.
  • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dicrotic notch is a distinctive feature on the aortic pressure curve that specifically marks the moment of aortic valve closure at the end of ventricular systole, representing the transition between systole and diastole.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest pH? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreatic juice

 

Explanation: 

 

Pancreatic juice has a pH of 8-8.3, making it the most alkaline (highest pH) among the given options. Pancreatic juice contains high concentrations of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻), which is secreted in response to secretin. In fact, the maximum HCO₃⁻ secretion in the GI tract occurs in the pancreas, contributing to its high alkalinity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastric juice - Has a pH of 1.2-3, making it highly acidic due to the secretion of HCl by parietal cells. This is the most acidic secretion in the GI tract.
  • Option B. Bile - While bile is alkaline in nature and contains bicarbonate, its pH is not as high as pancreatic juice. Bile serves as an excretory fluid and aids in fat emulsification.
  • Option D. Saliva - Has a pH of 6-7, making it slightly acidic to neutral. While it contains some bicarbonate, it's not as alkaline as pancreatic juice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic juice has the highest pH (8-8.3) among major GI secretions due to its high bicarbonate content, which is essential for neutralizing acidic chyme from the stomach to provide the optimal pH for pancreatic enzymes to function.

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Colon

 

Explanation:

 

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids decrease the number of circulating: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Eosinophils

 

Explanation: 

 

Glucocorticoids cause a significant decrease in the number of circulating eosinophils by increasing their sequestration in the spleen and lungs. This effect is a fundamental immunological action of glucocorticoids, with eosinophil counts typically dropping from around 275 to 50 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Neutrophils - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids actually increase the number of neutrophils in circulation. Neutrophil counts typically rise from approximately 4,000 to 10,000 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.
  • Option C. Platelets - This is incorrect as glucocorticoids increase rather than decrease platelet counts. Glucocorticoids lower the number of basophils in the circulation while increasing the number of neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells.
  • Option D. Red Blood Cells - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids increase the number of red blood cells in circulation, not decrease them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Glucocorticoids have diverse effects on blood cell populations, causing a reduction in eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes while increasing neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells through mechanisms involving altered cellular distribution and production.

questions.text: Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) acts on which of the following Tyrosine Receptor Kinases? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. TRK B

 

Explanation: 

 

Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) specifically binds to and activates TRK B receptors. TRK B (tropomyosin receptor kinase B) is a transmembrane receptor with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity. When BDNF binds to TRK B, it triggers autophosphorylation of the receptor, activating multiple signaling pathways including MAPK, PI3K, and PLCγ pathways. This activation plays crucial roles in neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity, particularly in long-term potentiation (LTP).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: TRK A serves as the high-affinity receptor for nerve growth factor (NGF), not BDNF. TRK A is primarily expressed in nociceptive neurons and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Option C: TRK C is the primary receptor for neurotrophin-3 (NT-3). It is predominantly expressed in proprioceptive neurons and plays important roles in sensory neuron development.
  • Option D: This is not a recognized member of the Trk receptor family. The mammalian Trk family consists only of TRK A, TRK B, and TRK C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BDNF specifically binds to TRK B receptors, initiating crucial signaling cascades that support neuronal survival, differentiation, and synaptic plasticity in the central nervous system.

questions.text: Which phenomenon is regulated by the asymmetrical distribution due to the Gibbs-Donnan effect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Chloride Shift

 

Explanation:

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the distribution of diffusible ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion cannot diffuse through the membrane. The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium establishes that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This principle directly governs the chloride shift, where chloride ions move across red blood cell membranes to maintain electrical neutrality.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Bohr Effect: This refers to hemoglobin's decreased affinity for oxygen when carbon dioxide increases or pH decreases, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option C. Haldane Effect: This describes how oxygenation of blood decreases its ability to carry carbon dioxide, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as chloride shift is regulated by Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect is fundamental to understanding ion distribution across semipermeable membranes, particularly explaining the chloride shift where chloride ions move into red blood cells as bicarbonate moves out.

questions.text: In the presence of elevated ADH levels, which part of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Proximal tubule

 

Explanation: 

 

The proximal tubule reabsorbs the largest percentage of filtered water (60-70%) even in the presence of ADH (vasopressin). This represents obligatory H₂O reabsorption that occurs regardless of hormonal status. The Loop of Henle handles 10-15% of water reabsorption, while the distal tubule and collecting ducts account for the remaining reabsorption, which is regulated by ADH as facultative H₂O reabsorption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Loop of Henle - Only reabsorbs 10-15% of filtered water, significantly less than the proximal tubule. Water reabsorption here occurs primarily in the descending limb due to the presence of aquaporin-1 channels.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Reabsorbs only 1-3% of water without ADH and up to 10-15% with ADH, still considerably less than the proximal tubule.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - While ADH has its most significant effect here (making it critical for concentrating urine), the absolute amount of water reabsorbed is less than in the proximal tubule. Approximately 14.7% total water reabsorption occurs in the collecting ducts (10% in cortical + 4.7% in medullary collecting ducts).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The proximal tubule performs the majority of water reabsorption (60-70%) through obligatory mechanisms independent of ADH, while ADH primarily regulates the facultative water reabsorption in the distal segments of the nephron.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

Alkalosis is the most frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany. This occurs because alkalosis decreases the ionized fraction of calcium in the blood without affecting total calcium levels. During alkalosis, more calcium becomes bound to plasma proteins (particularly albumin), reducing the physiologically active ionized calcium. Since only the ionized calcium is physiologically active, this reduction leads to tetany despite normal total calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Acidosis - Acidosis actually increases ionized calcium by reducing protein binding of calcium, which would protect against tetany rather than cause it.
  • Option C. Hypermagnesemia - Elevated magnesium levels typically cause CNS depression and hyporeflexia rather than tetany. Hypermagnesemia would not be expected to cause tetany with normal calcium levels.
  • Option D. Hypophosphatemia - While hypophosphatemia can affect calcium metabolism, it typically causes hypercalcemia rather than normocalcemia. It is not a frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalosis causes normocalcemic tetany by decreasing ionized calcium through increased protein binding, despite normal total calcium levels in the blood.

choices.text: Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin reduces its affinity for carbon dioxide
Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin makes it more acidic
Deoxygenated hemoglobin binds more hydrogen ions
Decrease in blood pH results in a lower affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following statements does NOT accurately describe the Haldane Effect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Decrease in blood pH results in a lower affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Explanation:

 

The Haldane effect specifically refers to the increased capacity of deoxygenated hemoglobin to bind and carry CO₂ compared to oxygenated hemoglobin. When hemoglobin releases oxygen in the tissues, it becomes better at binding CO₂ and H⁺. Conversely, when hemoglobin binds oxygen in the lungs, it releases CO₂ more readily. Statement D describes the Bohr effect (where decreased pH reduces oxygen binding), not the Haldane effect, making it the incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin reduces its affinity for carbon dioxide - This correctly describes the Haldane effect. When hemoglobin binds O₂ in the lungs, it releases CO₂ more easily, facilitating CO₂ excretion.
  • Option B. Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin makes it more acidic - This statement is accurate. Oxygenated hemoglobin is a stronger acid than deoxygenated hemoglobin because its imidazole groups dissociate more readily.
  • Option C. Deoxygenated hemoglobin binds more hydrogen ions - This is correct and essential to the Haldane effect. Deoxygenated hemoglobin has a greater capacity to bind H⁺ ions, making it a better buffer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Haldane effect (increased CO₂ carrying capacity of deoxygenated blood) and Bohr effect (decreased O₂ affinity with lower pH) are complementary but distinct physiological mechanisms that optimize gas exchange in tissues and lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones inhibits gastric motility and gastric emptying at physiological concentrations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Cholecystokinin

 

Explanation

 

Cholecystokinin (CCK) physiologically inhibits gastric motility and gastric emptying. It decreases gastric emptying by inhibiting the pylorus and causing contraction of the pyloric sphincter. This mechanism allows food to remain in the stomach longer, providing adequate time for digestion before the chyme enters the small intestine. This inhibitory effect coordinates with CCK's stimulatory effects on pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastrin Gastrin has the opposite effect on gastric emptying. It helps in pyloric sphincter relaxation and positively influences gastric emptying. By relaxing the pyloric sphincter, gastrin promotes rather than inhibits the movement of stomach contents into the duodenum.
  • Option C. GLP (Glucagon-Like Peptide) is produced by L cells in the intestine but doesn't have a primary role in inhibiting gastric motility or emptying at physiological concentrations. Its functions are primarily related to other gastrointestinal and metabolic processes.
  • Option D. Motilin Motilin increases GI motility rather than inhibiting it. Prokinetic drugs that stimulate motilin receptors (Mo cells) can cause diarrhea due to this stimulatory effect. Motilin promotes rather than inhibits gastric motility and is considered a prokinetic hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CCK physiologically inhibits gastric emptying by causing contraction of the pyloric sphincter, which works together with its other actions like gallbladder contraction and enzyme secretion to optimize digestion timing.

questions.text: Which law states that the amount of pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is proportional to the percentage of the gas in the mixture? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Dalton's law

 

Explanation: 

 

Dalton's law states that in a gas mixture, each individual gas exerts a partial pressure that is directly proportional to its percentage composition in the mixture. The formula PP = % Gas × Total pressure directly reflects Dalton's law, where each gas contributes to the total atmospheric pressure based on its fractional concentration. For example, at sea level with atmospheric pressure of 760 mmHg, oxygen (21%) exerts 160 mmHg, nitrogen (79%) exerts 600 mmHg, and CO₂ (0.04%) exerts 0.3 mmHg - each proportional to their respective percentages.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Graham's law - This law relates to the rate of diffusion of gases being inversely proportional to the square root of their molecular weights, not about pressure relationships in gas mixtures.
  • Option C. Henry's law - Henry's law specifically states that "gases that dissolve in the blood only they can generate the partial pressure in the blood." This law governs gas solubility in liquids, not the pressure exerted by gases in mixtures.
  • Option D. Boyle's law - Boyle's law is defined as P ∝ 1/V (pressure inversely proportional to volume). This law describes the relationship between pressure and volume of a gas at constant temperature, not the pressure contribution of individual gases in a mixture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dalton's law is fundamental to understanding respiratory gas exchange, as it explains how each respiratory gas (O₂, CO₂, N₂) contributes its specific partial pressure to the total atmospheric pressure based on its percentage composition.

questions.text: Which of the following is lined by simple squamous epithelium? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Loop of Henle

 

Explanation: 

                                   

Loop of Henle is lined by simple squamous epithelium. This specialized thin epithelium facilitates passive diffusion and reabsorption of water and electrolytes. The flattened cells with their minimal thickness are perfectly suited for the Loop of Henle's function in the renal tubular system, allowing efficient transport across the epithelial layer.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) - PCT is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with a prominent brush border. These cuboidal cells have numerous microvilli that increase surface area for active reabsorption of filtered substances.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. These cells have fewer microvilli than PCT cells but contain numerous mitochondria to support active transport processes.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - Collecting ducts are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. In some regions, particularly deeper parts, the epithelium may become columnar, but it is never squamous.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Simple squamous epithelium is found in areas requiring rapid transport, diffusion, or filtration such as the Loop of Henle, alveoli of lungs, and endothelium of blood vessels due to its thin, flattened morphology that facilitates these functions.

questions.text: All of the following are boundaries of the quadrangular space, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Supraspinatus

 

Explanation:

 

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical landmark in the scapular region where the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels pass. The correct boundaries of this space include teres minor superiorly (forming the superior boundary), teres major inferiorly (forming the inferior boundary), long head of triceps medially (forming the medial boundary), and the surgical neck of humerus laterally. Supraspinatus is not a boundary of this space - it lies in the supraspinous fossa of the scapula, superior to the region of the quadrangular space.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Teres minor: This is actually a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its superior border. It is one of the rotator cuff muscles originating from the lateral border of the scapula.
  • Option C. Teres major: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its inferior border. It originates from the dorsal surface of the inferior angle of the scapula.
  • Option D. Long head of triceps: This is a correct boundary of the quadrangular space, forming its medial border. It originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadrangular space is bounded by teres minor superiorly, teres major inferiorly, long head of triceps medially, and the surgical neck of humerus laterally - with the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral vessels as its contents.

questions.text: Which of the following thumb muscles is innervated by two different nerves? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B) Flexor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation:

 

Flexor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence that has a dual nerve supply. Its superficial head is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, while its deep head may receive innervation from the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This dual innervation makes it unique among the thumb muscles. The muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the trapezium, and inserts into the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It functions to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Flexor pollicis longus - This is a deep muscle of the anterior compartment of the forearm, not a thumb muscle proper. It is solely innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve).
  • Option C. Adductor pollicis - Located in the palm, this muscle is exclusively supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve (the "graveyard of the ulnar nerve").
  • Option D. Opponens pollicis - This is a thenar muscle that is exclusively innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It facilitates the opposition movement of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexor pollicis brevis is unique among thumb muscles due to its dual innervation pattern - the superficial head by the median nerve and the deep head by the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: The posterior superior iliac spine is at the level of?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. S2

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is an important bony landmark located at the posterior end of the iliac crest. The PSIS lies in the floor of a dimple about 5 cm lateral to the median plane and at the level of the second sacral spine (S2). This dimple is visible on the surface of the body and corresponds to the middle of the sacroiliac joint. The PSIS serves as an important landmark for various clinical examinations and procedures related to the lower back and pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. L5 - The highest point of the iliac crest corresponds to the interval between the spines of L3 and L4 vertebrae, not the PSIS. L5 is lower than this level but still above the level of PSIS.
  • Option B. S1 - The S1 vertebral level is above the level of the PSIS. The S1 foramen is an important landmark for nerve root identification, but it doesn't align with the PSIS.
  • Option D. S3 - The S3 vertebral level is below the level of the PSIS. The PSIS specifically aligns with the S2 vertebral level, not S3.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is located at the level of the second sacral spine (S2) and serves as a clinically important surface landmark for identifying the sacroiliac joint and related structures.

questions.text: The axillary artery is divided into three parts by?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Pectoralis minor

 

Explanation: 

 

The axillary artery is divided into three distinct parts by the pectoralis minor muscle. This key muscle of the axillary region serves as an important anatomical landmark that helps segment the axillary artery for descriptive purposes. Each part of the axillary artery gives specific branches: the first part (proximal to pectoralis minor) gives the superior thoracic artery; the second part (behind pectoralis minor) gives the thoracoacromial and lateral thoracic arteries; and the third part (distal to pectoralis minor) gives the anterior circumflex humeral, posterior circumflex humeral, and subscapular arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Scalenus anterior - This muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts, not the axillary artery. The subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery as it crosses the outer border of the first rib.
  • Option C. Teres minor - This muscle forms part of the rotator cuff and is related to the posterior wall of the axilla. It doesn't divide the axillary artery but forms part of the boundary of the quadrangular space.
  • Option D. Teres major - This muscle forms the lower boundary of the posterior wall of the axilla. The axillary artery ends at the lower border of teres major to become the brachial artery, but teres major doesn't divide the axillary artery into parts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pectoralis minor is the key muscle that divides the axillary artery into three parts, with each part giving rise to specific branches that supply the pectoral region and upper limb.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of lamellar bone? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Haversian system

 

Explanation:

 

The Haversian system (also called osteon) is the fundamental structural unit of compact lamellar bone. It's the defining microscopic feature of mature lamellar bone. Lamellar bone has a highly organized structure with thin sheets called lamellae arranged in concentric rings around a central Haversian canal, forming the complete Haversian system.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Bone marrow - While bone marrow is found within bones, it's not a characteristic feature of lamellar bone specifically. Bone marrow occupies the medullary cavity of long bones and spaces within cancellous bone but isn't part of the lamellar bone structure itself.
  • Option C. Strength and lightness - Though lamellar bone provides strength and lamellar arrangement contributes to mechanical properties; this is a functional characteristic rather than a structural feature. The Haversian system is the defining structural characteristic.
  • Option D. Trabeculae - Trabeculae are characteristic of cancellous/spongy bone, not compact lamellar bone. Trabeculae are meshworks of bony plates or rods that form the structure of spongy bone. Trabeculae do not contain Haversian systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Haversian system (osteon) is the defining microscopic structural unit of compact lamellar bone, consisting of concentric lamellae around a central canal containing blood vessels and nerves.

questions.text: How many intrinsic muscles of the hand are supplied by the ulnar nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 15

 

Explanation:

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 intrinsic muscles of the hand. These include all hypothenar muscles (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi), the palmaris brevis, all four palmar interossei, all four dorsal interossei, the adductor pollicis, and the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis (sometimes). The ulnar nerve is known as the "musician's nerve" because it controls fine movements of the fingers through its extensive motor distribution to these short muscles of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. 5 - This is incorrect. The median nerve supplies 5 muscles in the hand (thenar muscles - abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the first and second lumbricals).
  • Option B. 13 - This is incorrect. The number of intrinsic hand muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve is 15, not 13.
  • Option D. 17 - This is incorrect. The total number of intrinsic muscles in the hand is 20, of which 15 are supplied by the ulnar nerve and 5 by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 out of the 20 intrinsic muscles of the hand, making it the primary motor nerve of the hand and earning it the title of "musician's nerve" for its role in fine motor control of the fingers.

questions.text: The fabella is a sesamoid bone embedded in the tendon of?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Gastrocnemius

 

Explanation: 

 

The fabella is a sesamoid bone that is embedded specifically in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle. It is located in the posterior aspect of the knee joint where the lateral head of gastrocnemius originates. Sesamoid bones develop within tendons where they cross joint surfaces or bony prominences, and the fabella develops in the posterolateral aspect of the knee within the gastrocnemius tendon.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Quadriceps - This is incorrect because the quadriceps tendon contains the patella as its sesamoid bone, not the fabella. The patella is the largest sesamoid bone in the body.

C. Flexor carpi ulnaris - This is incorrect because the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon may contain a sesamoid bone (the pisiform) in the wrist, not the fabella which is located at the knee.

D. Popliteus - This is incorrect because the popliteus muscle does not contain any sesamoid bone. The popliteus is a triangular muscle located in the posterior knee region but does not contain the fabella.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The fabella is a small sesamoid bone found within the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle at the posterior aspect of the knee joint.

questions.text: Lymph from a cancerous breast primarily drains into which of the following nodes? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Anterior (pectoral) nodes

 

Explanation: 

 

The lymphatic drainage of the breast primarily flows into the anterior (pectoral) group of axillary lymph nodes. These nodes are positioned along the lateral thoracic vessels at the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle. Approximately 75% of the lymph from the breast tissue drains into the axillary nodes, with the anterior group receiving the major portion. This makes the anterior (pectoral) nodes the first-line lymph nodes to receive drainage from cancerous breast tissue, particularly from the upper lateral quadrant where breast cancer most commonly occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Apical nodes: Located at the apex of the axilla, these nodes receive lymph secondarily after it has passed through other axillary node groups. They're not the primary recipients of breast lymph drainage.
  • Option C. Parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes: These nodes receive about 20% of breast lymphatic drainage, primarily from the medial quadrants of the breast, but are not the main drainage pathway.
  • Option D. Supraclavicular nodes: These become involved primarily in advanced cases of breast cancer. They receive lymph only after it has passed through multiple other node groups.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anterior (pectoral) lymph nodes are the primary recipients of lymphatic drainage from the breast, making them crucial for early detection and staging of breast malignancy.

questions.text: Meckel’s diverticulum is a derivative of which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Vitellointestinal duct

 

Explanation: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct (also called vitelline duct, yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct). During embryonic development, the midgut communicates with the yolk sac through the vitellointestinal duct. Normally, this duct obliterates completely by the 7th week of development, but when the proximal part persists, it forms Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Allantoic diverticulum: This is a ventral projection of hindgut into the connecting stalk. Its proximal part gets incorporated into the apex of urinary bladder and its distal part undergoes fibrosis to form urachus. It has no relation to Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option C. Ventral mesogastrium: This is the embryological structure from which the lesser omentum and falciform ligament develop. It has no association with Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Option D. Ductus arteriosus: This is a vascular structure derived from the 6th aortic arch that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal life. After birth, it obliterates to form the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meckel's diverticulum follows the "rule of 2s" - it affects 2% of population, is about 2 inches long, occurs 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, is twice as common in males, and only 2% of patients are symptomatic.

questions.text: Referred pain from ureteric colic is felt in the groin due to involvement of the following nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. D) Genitofemoral

 

Explanation: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) is responsible for referred pain from ureteric colic felt in the groin. This nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch innervates the cremaster muscle and skin of the scrotum or labia majora, while the femoral branch supplies skin over the femoral triangle. When there is ureteric colic, the pain is referred along this nerve pathway to the groin area. The genitofemoral nerve is involved in the cremaster reflex, where scratching the inner thigh causes testicular elevation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Subcostal - This is a terminal branch of the T12 nerve that supplies the anterior abdominal wall. It doesn't have connections to the ureter that would explain referred pain to the groin.
  • Option B. Iliohypogastric - While this nerve (L1) is situated at the posterior surface of kidney, it primarily supplies the skin of the lower abdomen and hip region. It's not the main pathway for ureteric pain referred to the groin.
  • Option C. Ilioinguinal - This nerve (L1) supplies the inguinal region, upper part of scrotum, and root of penis or mons pubis in females. Though it runs near urological structures, it's not the primary nerve mediating referred ureteric pain to the groin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2) serves as the primary pathway for referred pain from ureteric colic to the groin due to its anatomical course and innervation of genital structures.

questions.text: The trans-inguinal descent of the testes occurs around: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C.  28 weeks

 

Explanation

 

The testes initially develop in the lumbar region of the posterior abdominal wall and undergo a gradual descent to the scrotum. This descent follows a specific timeline: the testes reach the iliac fossa during the 3rd month and remain at the deep inguinal ring until the 7th month of intrauterine life. The trans-inguinal descent (passage through the inguinal canal) occurs during the 7th month, which corresponds to approximately 28 weeks of gestation. By the end of the 8th month, the testes have normally completed their descent and are positioned in the scrotum.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. 8 weeks: At this early stage (2nd month), the testes are still in their initial position in the lumbar region.
  • Option B. 12 weeks: By the 3rd month, the testes have only reached the iliac fossa and have not yet approached the inguinal canal.
  • Option D. 33 weeks: By this time (late 8th month), the testes would have already completed their trans-inguinal descent and would be positioned in the scrotum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular descent follows a precise timeline: lumbar region (origin) → iliac fossa (3rd month) → deep inguinal ring (until 7th month) → trans-inguinal passage (7th month/28 weeks) → scrotal position (by 8th month).

choices.text: Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia
Between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia
Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia

questions.text: Where is the danger space in the neck located? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The danger space in the neck is located between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia. The alar fascia is an ancillary layer of deep cervical fascia which divides the retropharyngeal space into two parts. The posterior space between the alar fascia and prevertebral fascia is specifically called the "dangerous space in neck." This space is clinically significant because infections in this space can spread from the base of the skull to the mediastinum, as it has no anatomical barriers in the inferior direction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia - This space is the anterior part of the retropharyngeal space, not the danger space itself.

 

Option c) Between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia - This constitutes the entire retropharyngeal space, which is divided by the alar fascia into anterior and posterior components, with only the posterior component being the danger space.

 

Option d) None of the above - This is incorrect as option b correctly identifies the danger space location.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The danger space, located between the prevertebral fascia and alar fascia in the posterior part of the retropharyngeal space, is clinically important because infections here can spread extensively from the skull base to the mediastinum due to lack of inferior anatomical barriers.

questions.text: Which structure does not pass through the foramen ovale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. Instead, it enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, which is located posterolateral to the foramen ovale in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of the maxillary artery that supplies the dura mater and bones of the cranial cavity. It is clinically significant because its rupture can cause extradural hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b) Lesser petrosal nerve - This nerve passes through the foramen ovale. It carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the tympanic plexus to the otic ganglion.

 

Option c) Mandibular nerve - This is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V3) which exits the skull through the foramen ovale to enter the infratemporal fossa.
