Option d) Accessory meningeal artery - This artery passes through the foramen ovale along with the mandibular nerve and lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The foramen ovale transmits the mandibular nerve (V3), lesser petrosal nerve, and accessory meningeal artery, while the middle meningeal artery passes through the foramen spinosum.

questions.text: Among the given options, which layer of the scalp is vascular ? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Superficial fascia

 

Explanation:

 

The superficial fascia of the scalp is the highly vascular layer containing numerous blood vessels. This layer is more fibrous and dense in the center than at the periphery of the head. It contains many blood vessels and provides the proper medium for passage of vessels and nerves to the skin. The rich vascularity in this layer explains why scalp wounds bleed profusely, yet heal rapidly. The vessels in this layer are held open by the fibrous tissue when cut, making hemostasis more difficult.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Pericranium - This is the fifth or deepest layer of the scalp, which is the periosteum covering the skull bones. It's loosely attached to the surface of the bones except at the sutures where it's firmly adherent.

 

Option c) Skin - This is the outermost layer of the scalp that contains hair follicles, sweat glands and sebaceous glands, but is not the primary vascular layer.

 

Option d) Aponeurosis - This is the third layer of the scalp, also called galea aponeurotica or epicranial aponeurosis. It's a tough fibrous sheet connecting the frontalis and occipitalis muscles but is not particularly vascular.

 

Education Objective:

 

The superficial fascia of the scalp is the highly vascular layer containing numerous blood vessels that makes scalp injuries bleed profusely as these vessels are prevented from retracting due to the dense fibrous tissue surrounding them.

questions.text: Which of the following does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. Stylopharyngeus

 

 

Explanation:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni. Instead, it passes through the gap between the superior and middle constrictors of the pharynx. The stylopharyngeus arises from the styloid process and passes downwards between these constrictors to run on the inner surface of the pharyngeal wall.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory tube - The auditory tube (Eustachian tube) does pass through the sinus of Morgagni, which is the large gap between the upper concave border of the superior constrictor and the base of the skull. This semilunar gap is closed by the pharyngobasilar fascia.

 

Option B. Levator veli palatini - This muscle passes through the sinus of Morgagni. It enters the pharynx by passing over the upper concave margin of the superior constrictor, runs downwards and medially, and spreads out in the soft palate.

Option C. Ascending palatine artery - This artery passes through the sinus of Morgagni. It's a branch of the facial artery that ascends between the styloglossus and stylopharyngeus muscles and passes through the sinus to reach the soft palate.

 

Education Objective:

 

The sinus of Morgagni is a gap between the superior constrictor muscle and the base of the skull that allows passage of the auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, and ascending palatine artery—but not the stylopharyngeus muscle, which passes between the superior and middle constrictors.

questions.text: Which type of vertebrae feature a long spinous process? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b) Thoracic vertebrae

 

Explanation:

 

Thoracic vertebrae have long, slender, downward-directed spinous processes that are especially prominent in the mid-thoracic region. This characteristic feature is related to their functional role in providing attachment sites for the muscles of the back and for supporting the rib cage. The overlapping nature of these processes helps limit excessive extension of the thoracic spine, contributing to the stability of this region.

 

Other Options:

 

A) Cervical vertebrae - These have short, bifid (split) spinous processes rather than long ones. The bifid nature allows for attachment of multiple muscles while maintaining the neck's flexibility.

 

C) Lumbar vertebrae - Lumbar vertebrae have short, thick, horizontally-directed (rather than downward) spinous processes that are quadrangular in shape, designed to withstand greater stress in the lower back.

 

D) Sacrum - The sacrum is a fused bone consisting of five vertebrae, with rudimentary spinous processes that appear as the median sacral crest rather than distinct long processes.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Thoracic vertebrae are characterized by long, downward-sloping spinous processes that provide stability to the thoracic region and attachment points for back muscles while contributing to the limited mobility of this portion of the spine.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents with a weakened flexor pollicis longus and the flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger. Which nerve is likely involved? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explantion: 

 

The patient has weakness of flexor pollicis longus and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (supplying the index and middle fingers). These muscles are supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve. The anterior interosseous nerve is a deep motor branch of the median nerve that originates in the proximal forearm and supplies three deep muscles: the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus. This specific pattern of weakness suggests an anterior interosseous syndrome, which is a form of median nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (affecting the ring and little fingers), not the index finger portion. It does not innervate the flexor pollicis longus at all.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve: This is the deep terminal branch of the radial nerve that supplies extensor muscles of the forearm, not flexors. It has no connection to the flexor pollicis longus or flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Radial nerve: The radial nerve and its branches supply the extensor compartment of the forearm, including muscles like extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. It does not innervate any of the deep flexor muscles.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Weakness of flexor pollicis longus and the flexor digitorum profundus to the index finger is characteristic of anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, a motor branch of the median nerve, often called the "pinch grip" or "OK sign" deformity.

questions.text: Which area is innervated by the sensory region of the ulnar nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Tip of the little finger

 

Explanation:

The ulnar nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial 1½ digits of the hand, which includes the entire little finger (5th digit) and the medial half of the ring finger (4th digit). This includes both the palmar and dorsal aspects of these digits, along with their nail beds. The sensory distribution of the ulnar nerve extends to the tip of the little finger, making this the correct answer. In cases of ulnar nerve injury, patients typically experience sensory loss over this area, which can be demonstrated through clinical testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b) Tip of the index finger - This area is innervated by the median nerve, which supplies the lateral 3½ digits including the thumb, index, middle, and lateral half of the ring finger.

 

Option c) First web space - This is innervated by the superficial branch of the radial nerve on the dorsal aspect and the median nerve on the palmar aspect.

 

Option d) Lateral upper aspect of the arm - This area is innervated by the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, which is a branch of the axillary nerve, and not the ulnar nerve.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The ulnar nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial 1½ digits of the hand, including the entire little finger and medial half of the ring finger, making it crucial for sensory function of the medial aspect of the hand.

questions.text: Which nerve is found within Guyon's canal? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The ulnar nerve passes through Guyon's canal at the wrist before entering the hand. Compression of the ulnar nerve in this area is known as Guyon canal syndrome. Guyon's canal (also known as the ulnar canal) is a fibro-osseous tunnel at the wrist through which the ulnar nerve and ulnar artery pass. The canal is bounded by the pisiform bone medially, the hook of hamate laterally, and is covered by the volar carpal ligament (a superficial portion of the flexor retinaculum).

 

Other Options:

 

Option b) Radial nerve - The radial nerve does not pass through Guyon's canal. At the wrist level, the superficial branch of the radial nerve passes through the anatomical snuffbox on the lateral aspect of the wrist.

 

Option c) Median nerve - The median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel, not Guyon's canal. The carpal tunnel is located more laterally and is formed by the flexor retinaculum and carpal bones.

 

Option d) Anterior interosseous nerve - This is a branch of the median nerve that runs deep in the forearm and typically terminates before reaching the wrist, so it does not pass through Guyon's canal.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Guyon's canal contains the ulnar nerve and ulnar artery; compression of the ulnar nerve at this site results in Guyon canal syndrome, which presents with motor and/or sensory deficits in the ulnar nerve distribution of the hand.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for shoulder abduction between 15° and 90°? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Deltoid

 

Explanation:

 

The deltoid muscle is primarily responsible for abduction of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°. Specifically, the middle fibers of the deltoid are powerful abductors of the arm at the shoulder joint. The deltoid is a triangular muscle that covers the shoulder joint and gives the shoulder its rounded contour. It is innervated by the axillary nerve (C5, C6). The multipennate arrangement of its acromial fibers allows for strong abduction force, making it the main muscle for this movement range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Supraspinatus - While controversial, the supraspinatus is traditionally thought to initiate abduction (0°-15°) rather than being the primary muscle for 15°-90° abduction. It works synergistically with the deltoid throughout the range of motion.

 

Option b) Trapezius - The trapezius does not directly abduct the shoulder joint. Its role in shoulder abduction becomes important only beyond 90° when it rotates the scapula to allow continued overhead movement.

 

Option d) Serratus Anterior - This muscle is responsible for protraction of the scapula and works with the trapezius for scapular rotation during overhead abduction (90°-180°), but is not the primary muscle for 15°-90° glenohumeral abduction.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The deltoid muscle is the principal abductor of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°, while complete overhead abduction (beyond 90°) requires coordinated action between the deltoid, trapezius, and serratus anterior. According to latest edition of Gray’s Anatomy (0°-15°) is controversial. New updates are saying that (0°- 90°) movement is done by deltoid & supraspinatous both muscles.

questions.text: Which nerve injury is associated with winging of the scapula? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Long thoracic nerve of Bell

 

Explanation:

 

Winging of the scapula occurs due to paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle, which is supplied by the long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7). When damaged, the medial border of the scapula protrudes from the posterior chest wall, especially when the patient pushes against resistance. The person is unable to perform pushing or punching movements, and overhead abduction of the arm is affected. The serratus anterior normally holds the scapula against the thoracic wall, and its paralysis leads to this characteristic deformity where the inferior angle of the scapula becomes prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve: Supplies intrinsic hand muscles and causes ulnar claw hand when injured. It has no relation to the scapular muscles or position.

 

Option C. Lower subscapular nerve: Supplies the teres major and part of the subscapularis muscles. Its injury would affect shoulder rotation but not cause scapular winging.

 

Option D. Thoracodorsal nerve: Supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. Injury to this nerve affects extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the arm but does not cause winging of the scapula.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Winging of the scapula is pathognomonic of serratus anterior paralysis due to long thoracic nerve (Bell's nerve) injury, making it impossible for the patient to press against a wall without the medial border of scapula becoming abnormally prominent.

questions.text: Siffert-Katz sign is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blount’s disease

 

Siffert-Katz sign refers to a palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibial metaphysis and epiphysis, which can be associated with varus instability of the knee in early flexion (around 15-20 degrees). This sign indicates an intra-articular deformity characteristic of Blount's disease. 

 

The abnormal growth at the medial tibial growth plate in Blount's disease leads to this characteristic bony depression. When the knee is flexed to around 15-20 degrees, this depression can become more prominent and may be associated with varus instability (a tendency for the knee to buckle inwards).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perthes Disease is a condition affecting the hip joint in children, typically between the ages of 4 and 10. It involves a temporary disruption of blood supply to the femoral head, causing it to lose bone mass and potentially deform. The pathological changes occur in the femoral head and acetabulum, leading to symptoms like limping, hip pain, and restricted hip movement. There is no involvement of the proximal tibia or the specific posteromedial depression seen in Blount's disease. 

 

Option C: Osteogenesis Imperfecta presents with multiple fractures at various stages of healing due to bone fragility. It has specific radiographic findings related to thin cortices and multiple fractures, not the Siffert-Katz sign.

 

Option D: Pulled elbow (Nursemaid's elbow) is a subluxation of the proximal radioulnar joint. It typically has normal radiographs as it's primarily a soft tissue injury involving the annular ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Siffert-Katz sign, the palpable posteromedial depression of the proximal tibia associated with varus instability in early knee flexion, is a specific clinical finding that helps in the diagnosis of Blount's disease, particularly the infantile form. It reflects the unique way the proximal tibial growth plate is affected in this condition.

choices.text: It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tubercular osteomyelitis is not true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Periosteal reaction is characteristic

 

Periosteal reaction is not characteristic of tubercular osteomyelitis. In fact, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents as a well-defined area of bone destruction with minimal reactive new bone formation. This is distinctly different from pyogenic osteomyelitis where significant periosteal new bone formation is an important feature. The only exception is "Spina Ventosa" (tubercular dactylitis) where periosteal reaction can be seen in the digits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of secondary osteomyelitis - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis is always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body, commonly in the lungs or lymph nodes. The infection spreads to bone hematogenously.

 

Option B. Sequestrum is uncommon - This is actually true for typical tubercular osteomyelitis. While sequestra can occur, they are less common and less prominent compared to pyogenic osteomyelitis due to the more indolent nature of the infection.

 

Option D. Inflammation is minimal - This is true. Tubercular osteomyelitis causes a chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than the acute suppurative inflammation seen in pyogenic infections. The lesions are paucibacillary (containing few bacteria) with minimal inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unlike pyogenic osteomyelitis, tubercular osteomyelitis typically presents with well-defined bone destruction, minimal periosteal reaction, less prominent sequestrum formation, and chronic granulomatous inflammation rather than acute suppurative changes.

questions.text: Pipkin’s Fracture refers to a fracture of the (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Femoral Head

 

Pipkin's fracture refers to a fracture of the femoral head, which typically occurs in association with posterior hip dislocation. This injury results from a high-energy trauma like dashboard injuries in motor vehicle accidents. The Pipkin classification divides these fractures into four types based on the location of the fracture relative to the fovea centralis and associated injuries. These fractures are serious injuries that often require surgical intervention to restore joint congruity and prevent complications like avascular necrosis and post-traumatic arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal Tibia - Fractures of the distal tibia involving the articular surface are classified as pilon fractures or Ruedi-Allgower fractures, not Pipkin fractures.

 

Option C. Humeral Head - Fractures of the humeral head are part of proximal humerus fractures, which are classified by Neer's classification, not Pipkin's.

 

Option D. Distal Radius - Fractures of the distal radius are commonly classified as Colles' fractures, Smith's fractures, or Barton's fractures depending on the pattern. They are not related to Pipkin's classification.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pipkin's fracture is a specific type of femoral head fracture associated with posterior hip dislocation, representing a serious injury that often requires surgical management and carries risk of significant complications.

choices.text: Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament

questions.text: In which of the following meniscal tears will meniscectomy be a more suitable option than meniscal repair? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Tears in the inner zone

 

Meniscal tears in the inner zone (inner 2/3rd) are treated by excision (meniscectomy) rather than repair. This is because the inner 2/3rd of the meniscus is avascular, which means it has poor healing potential. In contrast, the peripheral 1/3rd of the meniscus receives blood supply and therefore can be repaired when torn since it has better healing potential.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tears in the outer zone - This is incorrect because the outer zone (peripheral 1/3rd) is vascular and has good healing potential, making it suitable for meniscal repair rather than meniscectomy.

 

Option B. Tears in the middle zone - This is partially incorrect. While the middle zone has less vascularity than the outer zone, tears at the junction of the middle and outer zones may still be amenable to repair depending on specific characteristics of the tear.

 

Option D. Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament - This is incorrect because this area is in the peripheral region of the meniscus which receives adequate blood supply, making repair a more suitable option than meniscectomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meniscectomy is preferred for tears in the inner avascular 2/3rd of the meniscus due to poor healing potential, while tears in the vascular peripheral 1/3rd are better treated with repair.

questions.text: Milkman’s fracture is a type of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Pseudofracture

 

Milkman's fracture is a type of pseudofracture found in bone softening disorders such as osteomalacia. These are not true fractures but rather indentations of the cortex due to arterial pulsations. They are also known as Looser's Zone or Umbauzanon. Milkman fractures commonly occur in the neck of femur (NOF) and pubic rami, appearing as radiolucent zones at sites of stress in radiographic imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicular fracture - Milkman's fracture is unrelated to a specific clavicular injury. While pseudofractures can occur in various bones, they are most commonly found in weight-bearing areas like the pubic rami and femoral neck in patients with underlying bone softening disorders.

 

Option C. Humeral fracture - Milkman's fracture is not a type of humeral fracture. Pseudofractures characteristically appear at sites where major blood vessels cross bone, creating pressure points that lead to cortical indentation.

 

Option D. Metacarpal fracture - Milkman's fracture does not refer to metacarpal injuries. These pseudofractures typically affect the axial skeleton and weight-bearing long bones in conditions like osteomalacia, hyperparathyroidism, and neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Milkman's fracture represents a pseudofracture (Looser's Zone) seen in bone softening disorders, primarily osteomalacia, appearing as cortical indentations at sites of arterial pulsation, commonly in the femoral neck and pubic rami.

questions.text: Which of the following represent Median Nerve Entrapment Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. All of the above

 

All three syndromes - Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, Pronator Syndrome, and Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome - involve entrapment of the median nerve at different anatomical locations. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is the most common entrapment syndrome, occurring at the wrist where the median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel. Pronator Syndrome involves compression of the median nerve at the proximal forearm beneath various structures including the ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origin of pronator teres or FDS. Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome specifically affects the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN), which is a motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Other Options: 

 

None of the individual options (A, B, or C) alone would be incorrect in this case since each syndrome represents a type of median nerve entrapment. The question asks which "represent Median Nerve Entrapment Syndrome" and all three conditions qualify.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Median nerve entrapment can occur at multiple anatomical locations resulting in distinct clinical syndromes: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (most common, at wrist), Pronator Syndrome (proximal forearm), and Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome (affecting the Anterior Interosseous branch).

questions.text: Infrapatellar bursitis is also known as? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Parson’s knee

 

Infrapatellar bursitis, also known as Parson's knee or Clergyman's knee, refers to the inflammation of the bursa located below the patella. This condition results from prolonged kneeling, which causes irritation and inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa. The term derives from the kneeling posture commonly adopted by clergymen during prayer, putting pressure on this specific bursa located beneath the patellar tendon at its attachment to the tibial tuberosity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Housemaid's knee - This is incorrect as Housemaid's knee specifically refers to prepatellar bursitis, which is inflammation of the bursa in front of the patella, not the infrapatellar bursa. This condition is named after housemaids who traditionally spent time kneeling while scrubbing floors.

 

 

Option C. Weaver's knee - This is incorrect as Weaver's bottom (not knee) refers to ischial bursitis. There is no recognized condition called "Weaver's knee" in orthopedic terminology.

 

Option D. Taylor's knee - This is incorrect. The term "Tailor's ankle" refers to lateral malleolus bursitis, but there is no established condition called "Taylor's knee" in orthopedic medicine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infrapatellar bursitis is known as Parson's knee or Clergyman's knee, while prepatellar bursitis is termed Housemaid's knee - distinguishing between these conditions involves identifying the exact anatomical location of the inflamed bursa.

questions.text: Knuckle Bender Splint is used for: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Ulnar Nerve Palsy

 

Knuckle Bender Splint is specifically used for ulnar nerve palsy to prevent or correct claw hand deformity. In ulnar nerve palsy, there is paralysis of the medial two lumbricals (which normally flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints), leading to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. The knuckle bender splint helps maintain the metacarpophalangeal joints in flexion, preventing the characteristic claw hand deformity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve Palsy - This requires a cock-up splint (not knuckle bender) to support the wrist in extension and prevent wrist drop, which is the characteristic deformity in radial nerve palsy due to paralysis of wrist extensors.

 

Option C. Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture - This condition results from forearm compartment syndrome and requires different management approaches including fasciotomy in acute stages and various reconstructive procedures later, not a knuckle bender splint.

 

Option D. CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) - This congenital foot deformity is managed with serial casting (Ponseti method) followed by bracing, not with a knuckle bender splint which is designed for hand deformities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The knuckle bender splint is specifically designed to maintain metacarpophalangeal joints in flexion to prevent or correct claw hand deformity in ulnar nerve palsy, while different splints like cock-up splints are used for other nerve palsies affecting the hand.

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Dissociative fugue

 

Explanation:

 

Dissociative fugue is marked by sudden, unexpected travel away from home or familiar surroundings. During a fugue, individuals often appear well-groomed and behave in a seemingly normal, goal-directed way, which reflects preserved self-care and orientation. However, once the fugue ends, they usually experience amnesia for what occurred during the episode. While in the fugue state, they might not even recognize anything is wrong and may deny memory issues. These episodes can last from minutes to months, and some individuals may have recurrent fugues. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue is considered a specifier of dissociative amnesia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Dissociative amnesia: This involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually related to trauma or stress, but it does not necessarily  include the travel or wandering behavior seen in fugue states. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia. 
  • Option C. Schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia may wander, but it’s typically disorganized or bizarre rather than purposeful. There are other signs also  like hallucinations, delusions, or negative symptoms. The person’s well-groomed appearance and coherent behavior is  against this diagnosis.
  • Option D. Dementia: Wandering can happen in dementia, but the onset is usually gradual, and the person often appears disheveled or confused. Dementia-related wandering stems from memory loss and impaired judgment, not dissociation. Plus, the sudden nature described in this case doesn't fit with how dementia typically presents.

 

Educational Objective:


If someone suddenly leaves home and ends up in a new place with intact self-care, normal-seeming behavior, and later has no memory of it, it must be dissociative fugue—especially if there are no psychotic or neurocognitive symptoms present.

choices.text: Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear

questions.text: All of the following are features of Pavor nocturnus except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear

 

In sleep terrors (pavor nocturnus), the individual usually returns to sleep quickly after the episode ends. Despite the dramatic nature of these episodes including a piercing scream, intense fear, and autonomic arousal patients typically have amnesia for the event and do not remain awake or fearful afterward. This feature helps distinguish sleep terrors from nightmares, where the person often wakes up fully, remains fearful, and has difficulty falling back asleep.

 

 Other options:

 

  • Option A. Occurs during NREM sleep: Sleep terrors arise from slow-wave sleep (NREM stages 3 and 4), usually within the first third of the night, when this stage is most prominent.
  • Option B. Often associated with panicky scream: A piercing scream or loud cry often marks the onset of a sleep terror. This is typically followed by signs of extreme fear—e.g., tachycardia, sweating, and dilated pupils.
  • Option D. Does not recall event: Amnesia for the event is characteristic. Patients are typically unresponsive during the episode and later unable to recall what happened, unlike nightmares, which are often remembered in vivid detail.

 

Educational Objective:


Sleep terrors are NREM parasomnias that begin with a loud scream and intense autonomic arousal but are usually followed by quick return to sleep and no memory of the event. They differ from nightmares in their sleep stage origin, behavioral features, and recall after the episode.

questions.text: Myxoedema Madness most frequently presents as: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Auditory Hallucination and Paranoia

 

Explanation:

 

In its most severe form, myxedema madness a term describing the psychiatric manifestation of severe hypothyroidism can present with a range of symptoms, including paranoia, depression, hypomania, and hallucinations. Auditory hallucinations are the most common form in psychiatric conditions generally, making auditory hallucination plus paranoia the most characteristic presentation in this context.

This combination can closely mimic paranoid psychosis or schizophrenia, particularly in elderly women with undiagnosed hypothyroidism. The pathophysiology involves thyroid hormone deficiency leading to widespread alterations in neurotransmitter balance, cerebral metabolism, and cognitive function, producing a full spectrum of mood and psychotic symptoms.

 

 Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression: While depression is commonly associated with hypothyroidism, visual hallucinations are less typical features in myxedema madness. Auditory hallucinations remain the most likely type when psychosis occurs.
  • Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia: Tactile hallucinations are more characteristic of substance-induced psychosis, such as that caused by stimulants (e.g., cocaine or methamphetamine), and are not commonly linked to hypothyroid states.
  • Option D. Paranoia and Depression: Both symptoms are indeed noted in myxedema madness, but this option omits hallucinations, which are part of the more complete and classic presentation in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Myxedema madness presents with a constellation of psychiatric symptoms, most characteristically paranoia with hallucinations (typically auditory), sometimes alongside depression and hypomania. Always consider hypothyroidism in cases of new-onset psychosis in older adults, especially when accompanied by physical signs like cold intolerance, bradycardia, dry skin, and weight gain.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Ganser Syndrome, except: (Neet PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Verbigeration. 

 

Explanation:


Ganser syndrome is a rare dissociative disorder most notable for the presence of "approximate answers"—a symptom known as vorbeigehen. Patients respond with incorrect but closely related answers that suggest an understanding of the question.

 

The syndrome is also commonly associated with:

 

Clouding of consciousness: manifesting as disorientation, confusion, amnesia, and impaired reality testing.

 

Hallucinations: often visual or auditory, occurring in many cases.

 

Somatic conversion symptoms: such as non-neurologic analgesia, shifting sensory deficits, or other functional neurologic signs sometimes described as "hysterical stigmata."

 

Verbigeration is a senseless repetition of one or several sentences or phrases. For example, a patient continued to repeat the following sentences for hours “Life is amazing. God is great. Children will come to meet soon. Its not a feature of Ganser’s syndrome 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Approximate Answers: This is actually the defining feature of Ganser syndrome. These nearly correct but inaccurate responses distinguish the condition.
  • Option B. Clouding of consciousness: A core component of Ganser syndrome. It often contributes to the presentation of confusion and impaired insight.
  • Option C. Somatic conversion: Often seen in Ganser syndrome, especially in the form of conversion symptoms like numbness, non-anatomic sensory changes, or motor deficits that don’t follow neurologic patterns.

 

Educational Objective:


Ganser syndrome is best remembered by its hallmark triad:

  1. Approximate answers (vorbeigehen)
  2. Clouding of consciousness
  3. Hallucinations
     It may also present with conversion symptoms, but verbigeration is not part of the typical clinical picture and is more aligned with psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Kleine-Levin syndrome (KLS), EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anorexia

 

Explanation:


Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS), sometimes referred to as “Sleeping Beauty Syndrome,” is a rare sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of:

  • Hypersomnia (sleeping up to 18–20 hours a day),
  • Hyperphagia (excessive eating),
  • Hypersexuality, and
  • Behavioral disinhibition.

 

These episodes typically last days to weeks, and in between episodes, individuals return to baseline functioning. KLS most often begins in male adolescents, usually between the ages of 10 -21years. KLS is marked by hyperphagia, not reduced appetite (Anorexia). The presence of voracious eating during episodes is a defining characteristic that helps differentiate it from other conditions with excessive sleepiness.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: This is a well-known nickname for KLS, reflecting the extended sleep durations during episodes.
  • Option C. Hypersomnia: This is a core diagnostic feature. Patients often sleep nearly continuously for days, only waking to eat or use the bathroom.
  • Option D. Hypersexuality: Frequently observed in KLS. It includes increased libido, inappropriate sexual behavior, or disinhibition during episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kleine-Levin Syndrome is defined by episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality, with complete resolution between episodes.

questions.text: Following are mature defense mechanisms, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Denial

 

Explanation:

 

Denial is classified as an immature defense mechanism, not a mature one. It involves the refusal to accept reality or facts, thereby protecting the individual from experiencing painful emotions or external threats. While it may offer short-term emotional relief, over time it can impair functioning by distorting reality and preventing adaptive coping.

 

In contrast, mature defense mechanisms are considered healthy and adaptive ways of managing internal conflict and stress. They help individuals handle difficult emotions without distorting reality or harming others.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Altruism: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • Option B. Humor: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • Option C. Anticipation: It’s a mature defense mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:


Defense mechanisms lie on a spectrum from immature to mature. The following are mature defense mechanisms-

  1. Sublimation: Transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. E.g. A middle-aged man with unacceptable sexual desire becomes a painter and starts making nude paintings
  2. Anticipation: Preparing in advance for an unpleasant situation. E.g. A student plans all his arguments comprehensively before telling his father about a bad exam result.
  3. Humour: Use of comedy to deal with an unpleasant situation. E.g  Two medical students joked and laughed at themselves after getting humiliated by the examiner during the viva
  4. Altruism: Use of a social cause to deal with own emotions. E.g. After losing his son in an accident while driving drunk, a man launched an anti-drunk driving campaign, educating others about the dangers of driving under the influence.
  5. Suppression: A voluntary decision not to think about an event for some time and avoid the accompanying emotions. E.g. A highly stressed medical student, facing an upcoming entrance exam, chooses to take a one-day break and doesnt think about the exam at all. It is the only voluntary/conscious defense mechanism

questions.text: How many stages are described in Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model of 'coping with dying'? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Five

 

Explanation:

 

The Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model outlines five stages of grief. These stages were based on her work with terminally ill patients, though they have since been applied more broadly to anyone experiencing loss.

 

The five stages are:

 

 

These stages are not necessarily linear, and individuals may cycle through them in various orders or revisit stages over time.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Three: Some alternative models of grief suggest three phases (e.g., acute grief, integrated grief, and recovery), but this is not part of Kübler-Ross’s framework.
  • Option B. Four: While simplified adaptations might omit or combine stages, the original Kübler-Ross model contains five clearly defined stages.
  • Option D. Six: Some later interpretations have proposed a sixth stage (like "finding meaning", as suggested by David Kessler), but the classic Kübler-Ross model includes only five.

 

Educational Objective:


The Kübler-Ross model remains a foundational framework in understanding grief and loss, consisting of five stages denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance though experiences of grief are highly individual and not always stage-based.

questions.text: Which of the following is more common in Anorexia Nervosa when compared to Bulimia Nervosa? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Amenorrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Amenorrhea is more frequently associated with anorexia nervosa, primarily due to the effects of significant caloric restriction and weight loss on the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Starvation leads to a drop in GnRH, which lowers FSH and LH levels, resulting in decreased estrogen and subsequent menstrual irregularities or absence. While amenorrhea was once a diagnostic criterion in DSM-IV and ICD-10, it is no longer required in DSM-5 or ICD-11—but it remains a common clinical feature.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Dental Caries: More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia.
  • Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism.
  • Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.

 

Educational Objective:


Amenorrhea is a hallmark physiological consequence of the nutritional and hormonal imbalances seen in anorexia nervosa. Recognizing this and other subtle distinctions between anorexia and bulimia can help guide both diagnosis and management.

choices.text: It is the most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children.
Initial management typically involves prednisolone at 60 mg/day.
Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is INCORRECT? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Remission is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio >2.

 

Remission in minimal change disease is indicated by a urine protein: creatinine ratio <0.2 (not >2). Remission is defined as "urine albumin nil or trace (or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr) for 3 consecutive early morning specimens." A protein ratio >2 would actually indicate heavy proteinuria of nephrotic range proteinuria, not remission.

 

Remission criteria are specifically defined as early morning urine showing protein nil/trace for 3 consecutive days or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr. A ratio >2 would indicate ongoing disease activity rather than resolution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease (MCD) is indeed the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, accounting for approximately 90% of cases of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option B. The prognosis of minimal change disease is generally good, with >95% of patients responding to steroid therapy. Most patients outgrow the condition by adulthood.

 

Option C. Initial management involves prednisolone at a dose of 2 mg/kg/day (maximum 60 mg) for 6 weeks followed by alternate day therapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remission in nephrotic syndrome is defined by the absence of proteinuria (nil/trace) for 3 consecutive days or proteinuria <4 mg/m²/hr, while a urine protein ratio >2 indicates ongoing heavy proteinuria, not remission.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Phenylketonuria (PKU) is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Excess Melanin

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is characterized by decreased melanin, not excess melanin. PKU is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. This deficiency leads to increased levels of phenylalanine in the blood and decreased levels of tyrosine. Since tyrosine is a precursor for melanin synthesis, patients with PKU have decreased melanin production, resulting in characteristic physical features including blonde hair, fair skin, and blue eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficient Tyrosine - This is actually correct. In PKU, the body cannot convert phenylalanine to tyrosine due to the enzyme deficiency, resulting in decreased tyrosine levels.

 

Option B. Excess Phenylalanine - This is correct. PKU results in elevated levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate) due to the enzymatic defect.

 

Option D. Autosomal Recessive - This is correct. PKU follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, requiring mutations in both copies of the phenylalanine hydroxylase gene.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phenylketonuria results in decreased (not increased) melanin production, leading to characteristic features like fair skin, blonde hair and blue eyes due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis.

questions.text: Analyze the pedigree provided. Which mode of inheritance does it suggest? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

This pedigree shows a pattern consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Key features supporting this conclusion include:

  • Only females transmit the trait (maternal inheritance pattern).
  • All children (sons and daughters) of affected mothers are affected.
  • No children of affected fathers are affected.
  • The trait appears in every generation via the maternal line only.
  • Male-to-offspring transmission is absent, which is a hallmark of mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive – Incorrect

Autosomal recessive conditions typically show a horizontal pattern (affecting siblings rather than parent-to-child transmission). They often skip generations and require both parents to be carriers. In contrast, this pedigree shows consistent maternal transmission without generational skipping.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant – Incorrect

Autosomal dominant inheritance shows vertical transmission with equal male and female transmission, and affected fathers can pass the trait to their children. However, in this pedigree, affected males do not transmit the trait at all, which is not compatible with autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant – Incorrect

X-linked dominant inheritance shows father-to-daughter transmission (all daughters of affected fathers are affected, but sons are not). This pattern is not seen in the pedigree, and males do not transmit the condition, ruling out X-linked dominance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission only. All children of affected mothers inherit the condition, whereas no children of affected fathers are affected, due to the exclusive maternal origin of mitochondrial DNA. Both males and females may be affected, but only females pass on the trait.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a substantially greater risk of developing epilepsy after febrile seizures? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Family history of Febrile Seizure

 

Family history of febrile seizures is primarily associated with recurrence of febrile seizures rather than development of epilepsy. While it increases the likelihood of having another febrile seizure, it doesn't substantially raise the risk of developing epilepsy. The risk factors table shows that epilepsy risk is 1% after simple febrile seizures, 6% after complex febrile seizures, and much higher (29-33%) with neurodevelopmental abnormalities or family history of epilepsy (18%).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complex Febrile seizures - Complex febrile seizures increase the risk of developing epilepsy to approximately 6%, which is six times higher than with simple febrile seizures.

 

Option C. Developmental Delay - Neurodevelopmental abnormality carries a 33% risk of subsequent epilepsy development, making it one of the strongest risk factors.

 

Option D. Epilepsy in first-degree relatives - Family history of epilepsy increases the risk to approximately 18%, which is significantly higher than the baseline risk.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While family history of febrile seizures increases the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures, it does not substantially increase the risk of developing epilepsy, unlike neurodevelopmental abnormalities, complex febrile seizures, or family history of epilepsy.

questions.text: In a patient with a left-to-right shunt, the presence of pulmonary plethora, an enlarged left atrium, and a normal aorta suggests which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

 

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is characterized by a left-to-right shunt that leads to increased pulmonary blood flow. In VSD, blood shunted from the left ventricle passes through the VSD and is ejected into the pulmonary artery, resulting in pulmonary plethora (increased pulmonary vascularity). The increased blood flow returns to the left atrium, causing left atrial enlargement. The cardiac silhouette in VSD shows a left ventricular type with normal aorta. These findings are classic for VSD - pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, and normal aortic size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) - In ASD, there is right atrial and right ventricular enlargement with prominent pulmonary artery segments. Left atrial enlargement is typically not seen in isolated ASD as the shunt is pre-tricuspid. The left atrium does not enlarge in size in atrial septal defect unless associated with other anomalies.

 

Option C. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) - In PDA, there would typically be enlargement of the aorta, particularly the ascending aorta and aortic knuckle, along with left atrial and left ventricular enlargement. The ascending aorta and the aortic knuckle are prominently visible on chest X-ray, which contradicts the finding of a normal aorta in the question.

 

Option D. None of the above - This is incorrect because VSD fits the described findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ventricular septal defect is characterized by pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, and a normal or small aorta, which distinguishes it from other left-to-right shunts like ASD (which shows RA and RV enlargement) and PDA (which shows aortic enlargement).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ataxia Telangiectasia is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Selective absence of IgM

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia is associated with IgA deficiency, not selective IgM deficiency. These children may have IgA deficiency or impaired cell mediated immunity, frequent sinopulmonary infections and increased predisposition to lymphoreticular malignancies. Immunological abnormalities are common in Ataxia Telangiectasia, but specifically IgA deficiency is mentioned, not IgM deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Premature ageing - This is a correct statement about Ataxia Telangiectasia, which is characterized by premature aging and is classified as a progeroid syndrome.

 

Option C. Insulin-dependent Diabetes Mellitus - This is a correct statement as higher incidence of diabetes mellitus is associated with Ataxia Telangiectasia. The text specifically mentions there is a higher incidence of diabetes mellitus in patients with Ataxia Telangiectasia.

 

Option D. Progressive Cerebellar Ataxia - This is a correct statement and is the hallmark feature of Ataxia Telangiectasia. The disease is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia starting at 1-3 years.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia typically presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasia of the conjunctiva and skin, elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, and immunodeficiency (specifically IgA deficiency and impaired cell-mediated immunity), along with increased risk of malignancy and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Alagille Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Peroxisomal biogenesis disorder

 

Alagille syndrome is not a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder. It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in JAG1 gene that affects multiple organ systems including the liver, heart, eyes, and skeleton. The syndrome is characterized by bile duct paucity leading to cholestatic jaundice, butterfly vertebrae, characteristic facial features (including prominent forehead, deep-set eyes, and pointed chin), and cardiac anomalies, particularly right-sided cardiac defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous xanthoma - This is actually a true feature of Alagille syndrome. Patients often develop xanthomas due to chronic cholestasis and resulting hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option C. Arteriohepatic dysplasia - This is another name for Alagille syndrome, referring to the combination of hepatic and vascular manifestations of the disease, so this statement is true.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot - This is a true association of Alagille syndrome. Cardiac manifestations are common in Alagille syndrome, with Tetralogy of Fallot and pulmonary artery stenosis being the most frequent cardiac abnormalities seen. Alagille syndrome is associated with "Pulmonary artery stenosis, TOF."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alagille syndrome is an arterio-hepatic dysplasia characterized by bile duct paucity, butterfly vertebrae, distinctive facial features, and cardiac defects (particularly TOF and pulmonary stenosis), but it is not a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following are the first permanent teeth to erupt in children? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. First Molar

 

The first permanent teeth to erupt in children are the first molars. According to the developmental milestone. the first permanent teeth to appear are the first molars at around 6-7 years of age. This is specified in the section on dentition which states: "1st Permanent Teeth to appear: 1st Molar (6 yr)." The eruption of the first permanent molar typically occurs before the eruption of permanent incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First Premolar - Incorrect because the first premolars erupt later in the sequence of permanent dentition, usually around 10-11 years of age according to the dentition table. They come after the permanent incisors and first molars have already erupted.

 

Primary dentition - Mnemonic – IIMCM

 

 

Permanent teeth - Mnemonic - Mom is in pain, Papa can make medicine.

 

 

Option C. Lateral Incisor - Incorrect because permanent lateral incisors erupt at around 8-9 years of age (upper) and 7-8 years (lower), after the eruption of central incisors which appear at 7-8 years (upper) and 6-7 years (lower).

 

Option D. Canine - Incorrect because permanent canines erupt even later, at around 11-12 years of age (upper) and 10-12 years (lower), well after the first molars, incisors, and premolars have erupted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The first permanent teeth to erupt in children are the first molars at approximately 6-7 years of age, often called the "6-year molars," which erupt before the shedding of primary teeth begins.

questions.text: Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are related to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are specifically used in the staging and prognostication of maxillary sinus carcinoma. Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. This line divides the maxillary sinus into anteroinferior and posterosuperior portions, which has significant prognostic implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellopontine angle tumor: These tumors are classified using different systems related to their location in the posterior cranial fossa. Ohngren's line has no relevance to cerebellopontine angle tumors, which include acoustic neuromas and meningiomas.

 

Option C. Glomus Jugulare Tumor: These tumors are classified based on their extension from the jugular foramen and involvement of surrounding structures. The Fisch classification system is typically used, not Ohngren's classification.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma of eyelid: These tumors are classified according to their histopathological features and TNM staging. Ohngren's line is not used in the classification or prognostication of basal cell carcinomas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ohngren's line is a critical prognostic indicator in maxillary sinus carcinoma; tumors situated posterosuperior to this line (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those anteroinferior to it (infrastructural) due to their proximity to vital structures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for diagnosing suspected lateral sinus thrombosis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laugier’s Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Laugier's sign is not used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is actually a sign associated with fracture of the zygomatic arch, where tenderness is elicited on pressing the fractured fragments. This sign has no relationship to lateral sinus thrombosis or any other otological condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Queckenstedt's Test: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis diagnosis. Also called the Tobey-Ayer test, it involves compression of the jugular vein while monitoring CSF pressure via lumbar puncture. In lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side's jugular vein causes no change in CSF pressure, while compression of the normal side increases CSF pressure.

 

Option B. Crowe-Beck Test: This is correctly used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is an alternative to Queckenstedt's test that avoids lumbar puncture. It involves observing retinal vein engorgement through fundoscopy during jugular compression. With lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side causes no retinal vein engorgement, while compression of the normal side does.

 

Option C. Griesinger's Sign: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis. It refers to edema and tenderness over the mastoid emissary vein (posterior to the mastoid process), which occurs due to thrombophlebitis extending from the lateral sinus to the emissary vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Queckenstedt's test, Crowe-Beck test, and Griesinger's sign are all valid diagnostic indicators for lateral sinus thrombosis, Laugier's sign is unrelated and specifically associated with zygomatic arch fractures.

questions.text: Otosclerosis most commonly begins at which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fissula Ante-fenestram

 

Explanation:

 

Otosclerosis most commonly begins at the fissula ante fenestram. This is a small depression located in front of the oval window in the otic capsule. This is the initial site where the abnormal bone remodeling process begins, which eventually extends to involve the stapes footplate causing its fixation and conductive hearing loss. The fissula ante fenestrum is considered the classic starting point for otosclerotic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram: While otosclerotic foci can develop in various locations within the otic capsule, the fossula post-fenestram (behind the oval window) is not the most common initial site. Otosclerosis predominantly begins at the area anterior to the oval window (fissula ante fenestram).

 

Option C. Footplate of Stapes: Although the stapes footplate is eventually involved in otosclerosis, leading to the characteristic stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss, it is not typically the primary site where the disease process begins. The disease usually starts in the fissula ante fenestram and then extends to involve the footplate.

 

Option D. Oval Window: The oval window itself is not the initial site of otosclerotic change. The oval window is the opening between the middle and inner ear into which the stapes footplate fits. Otosclerosis begins in the bone adjacent to this structure (in the fissula ante fenestram) and then extends to involve the stapes footplate and oval window area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otosclerosis characteristically begins in the fissula ante fenestram (anterior to the oval window) before extending to involve the stapes footplate, causing the fixation that leads to conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

 

Explanation:

 

Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenger's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.

 

Option C. Lombard's Test: This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.

 

Option D. Erhardt's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes infection involving the geniculate ganglion? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is characterized by facial palsy due to herpes zoster infection (varicella-zoster virus) involving the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve. It presents as a triad of facial nerve palsy, vesicular eruptions on the pinna and external auditory canal, and vestibulocochlear symptoms. The infection represents a reactivation of the herpes zoster virus that had remained dormant in the geniculate ganglion after previous chickenpox infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heerfordt Syndrome: This is a rare manifestation of sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of uveitis, parotid gland enlargement, and facial nerve palsy. It is not related to herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion. The facial palsy in this condition is due to granulomatous infiltration of the facial nerve.

 

Option C. Bell's Palsy: While this is also a facial nerve paralysis, Bell's palsy is idiopathic in nature. Although some theories suggest that herpes simplex virus may be involved in some cases of Bell's palsy, it does not specifically involve vesicular eruptions or definitive evidence of geniculate ganglion involvement as seen in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Option D. Melkersson's Syndrome: This syndrome (also called Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome) is characterized by recurrent or persistent facial swelling, recurrent facial paralysis, and a fissured tongue (lingua plicata). It is not caused by herpes infection of the geniculate ganglion but is thought to be related to granulomatous disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is specifically characterized by facial nerve palsy due to herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion, presenting with the distinctive triad of facial paralysis, ear/mouth vesicles, and auditory/vestibular symptoms.

questions.text: What is the length of the external auditory canal in an adult? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 mm

 

Explanation:

 

The external auditory canal in an adult measures about 24 mm along its posterior wall. This is the standard anatomical length of the external auditory canal. The canal is not straight but has a slight S-shape, with the outer part directed upwards, backwards, and medially, while the inner part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 16 mm: This is incorrect for the total length of the external auditory canal. However, 16 mm specifically represents the length of the bony part of the external auditory canal, which forms the inner two-thirds of the total canal.

 

Option B. 20 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is longer than 20 mm in adults.

 

Option D. 28 mm: This is incorrect. The external auditory canal is shorter than 28 mm in adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The external auditory canal in adults measures approximately 24 mm along its posterior wall and consists of a cartilaginous part (outer one-third, approximately 8 mm) and a bony part (inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm).

questions.text: Which phenomenon describes vertigo induced by loud sounds? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tullio Phenomenon

 

Explanation:

 

Tullio phenomenon refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus in response to loud sounds. This occurs due to a pathological connection between the sound-conducting system and the vestibular apparatus. Loud sounds cause abnormal stimulation of the vestibular system, resulting in vestibular symptoms. This phenomenon is seen in conditions like superior semicircular canal dehiscence, perilymphatic fistula, and advanced otosyphilis where there is an abnormal communication between the inner ear fluid compartments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hennebert's Sign: This refers to the development of vertigo and nystagmus on applying pressure to the external auditory canal (positive fistula test) in the absence of a demonstrable fistula (false positive). It is typically seen in congenital syphilis due to the presence of fibrous adhesions between the stapes footplate and the membranous labyrinth. Unlike Tullio phenomenon which is triggered by sound, Hennebert's sign is elicited by pressure changes.

 

Option C. Roll-over Phenomenon: This is seen in retrocochlear hearing loss (e.g., acoustic neuroma). It refers to a decrease in speech discrimination scores as the intensity of sound is increased beyond a certain level. Unlike Tullio phenomenon, it does not involve vertigo and is related to hearing discrimination rather than vestibular function.

 

Option D. Recruitment Phenomenon: This is the abnormal growth of loudness perception seen in cochlear hearing loss. Patients with cochlear lesions have difficulty hearing soft sounds, but as intensity increases, they perceive loudness as rapidly growing to normal or even uncomfortable levels. This phenomenon affects hearing rather than balance and does not cause vertigo.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tullio phenomenon specifically describes the vestibular symptoms (vertigo and nystagmus) induced by loud sounds due to pathological communication between the sound-conducting and vestibular systems of the inner ear.

questions.text: What is the term for a primary skin lesion that is flat, without elevation or depression, and less than 1 cm in diameter? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macule

 

  • A macule is a circumscribed, flat lesion of skin that is visible because of a change in skin color. 

 

 

  • It is neither elevated nor depressed, has no change in skin texture, and by definition is less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Macules can be hyperpigmented (like fixed drug eruption), hypopigmented (like leprosy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papule 

 

  • A papule is a small, solid, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Unlike macules, papules project above the skin surface and 

 

Option C. Patch 

 

  • A patch is similar to a macule in that it is flat and has a color change, but by definition, a patch is larger than 1 cm in diameter. 

 

Option D. Vesicle 

 

  • A vesicle is a fluid-filled, circumscribed, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Vesicles form due to a split in the skin and contain clear fluid.

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • A macule is a flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm in diameter that represents a change in skin color without alteration in skin texture or thickness.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a focal non-cicatricial cause of alopecia? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cicatricial (scarring) form of alopecia, not a non-cicatricial cause. 

 

 

  • DLE destroys hair follicles, leading to permanent hair loss with scarring. 
  • It's specifically classified under "Connective tissue diseases" in scarring alopecias. 
  • When DLE affects the scalp, it leads to inflammatory lesions that heal with scarring, resulting in irreversible hair loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • This is correctly classified as a non-cicatricial alopecia. 
  • It's characterized by circular patches of complete hair loss with exclamation mark hairs at the periphery. 

 

 

  • Hair follicles remain preserved, making it potentially reversible.

 

Option B. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • Secondary syphilis can cause a moth-eaten, patchy pattern of hair loss, which is non-cicatricial. 

 

 

Option C. Black Dot Type Tinea Capitis:

 

  • This is a non-inflammatory type of tinea capitis where infected hairs break off at the scalp surface, leaving behind characteristic black dots.

 

 

  • It is non-cicatricial, as there is no permanent follicular damage. 
  • However, other inflammatory forms of tinea capitis like kerion (boggy inflammatory mass) and favus (yellow cup-shaped crusts) can destroy hair follicles and cause cicatricial alopecia if not treated early.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cause of focal cicatricial alopecia and thus is not classified among focal non-cicatricial causes of hair loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical histological feature of Lichen Planus? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Munro microabscess.

 

  • This is not a feature of lichen planus. 
  • Munro microabscesses are collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum, and are a hallmark of psoriasis, not lichen planus. 

 

 

  • Their presence helps differentiate psoriasis from lichenoid dermatoses histologically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Max Joseph Cleft:

 

  • The Max Joseph space is an artifactual cleft that forms at the dermo-epidermal junction due to the extensive basal cell damage in lichen planus.

 

Option B. Civatte bodies:

 

  • Civatte bodies (also called colloid bodies) are apoptotic keratinocytes that appear as eosinophilic, rounded structures in the lower epidermis and papillary dermis of lichen planus lesions.

 

Option C. Sawtooth profile of rete ridges:

 

  • The sawtooth appearance of the rete ridges is characteristic of lichen planus and results from the irregular acanthosis combined with basal cell damage.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Munro microabscesses are a classical histological feature of psoriasis, not lichen planus, which is characterized by Max Joseph clefts, Civatte bodies, and sawtooth rete ridges.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by the presence of mica-like adherent scales? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis lichenoides chronica

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica (PLC) is specifically characterized by mica-like adherent scales. 
  • This chronic papulosquamous condition presents with polymorphic eruptions of successive crops of asymptomatic red-brown papules, which are surmounted by a central, adherent mica-like scale. 

 

 

  • These scales have a distinctive shiny, flaky appearance resembling mica mineral. 

 

 

 

  • The lesions of PLC heal with hypopigmentation and commonly affect the trunk and proximal parts of the extremities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis features silvery white, loose, lamellar scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are easily removable and when scraped, demonstrate the Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding spots). 
  • Psoriatic scales are described as micaceous, silvery white, but they are not adherent like those in PLC.

 

Option B. Pityriasis rosea:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is characterized by a collarette of scales on the leading edge of lesions, not mica-like adherent scales. 
  • The scales in pityriasis rosea have their outer edge attached within the active margin of the lesion, while the inner edge remains free (which produces the "hanging curtain sign" when stretched).

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis features greasy or yellowish scales rather than mica-like adherent scales. 

 

 

  • These scales are typically found in sebum-rich areas of the body, such as the scalp, face, and flexures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis lichenoides chronica is distinguished by its mica-like adherent scales surmounting red-brown papules, which heal with characteristic hypopigmentation — a key diagnostic feature that differentiates it from other papulosquamous disorders.

questions.text: What is the most accurate description of Eczema marginatum? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinea cruris

 

  • Eczema marginatum is another name for Tinea cruris, which is a dermatophyte infection of the groin area. 

 

 

  • It is also colloquially referred to as "jock itch" or "dhobi itch."
  • Tinea cruris presents as an annular, sharply demarcated plaque with peripheral scaling, inner aspects of the thighs. 
  • The infection expands centrifugally with central clearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea capitis:

 

  • Tinea capitis refers to a dermatophyte infection of the scalp and hair, not the groin. 
  • It typically manifests as patches of hair loss with scaling and can present as black dot, gray patch, kerion, or favus variants depending on the causative organism and host immune response.

 

Option B. Tinea barbae: 

 

  • Tinea barbae refers to a fungal infection of the beard area in men. 
  • It is not the same as Eczema marginatum, which affects the groin area. 
  • Tinea barbae involves the coarse terminal hair of the beard and can cause follicular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Tinea unguium:

 

  • Tinea unguium refers to a dermatophyte infection of the nail plate. 

 

 

  • It presents with discoloration, thickening, and crumbling of the nail plate with subungual hyperkeratosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eczema marginatum is synonymous with Tinea cruris (fungal infection of the groin), characterized by annular, well-demarcated plaques with active margins showing scaling and inflammation, most commonly affecting the inner thighs and groin area.

choices.text: Presence of Circle of Hebra lesions
Scalp and face are spared in infants
Norwegian scabies is the most severe form
Burrows are found in the stratum corneum

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding scabies? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scalp and face are spared in infants

 

  • The statement that "Scalp and face are spared in infants" is incorrect regarding scabies. 
  • In infants and young children, scabies frequently involves the scalp, face, neck, and even the palms and soles.
  • This is in contrast to adults, where the head and neck are usually spared (except in crusted/Norwegian scabies). 
  • The predilection for head and face involvement in infants is an important diagnostic feature of infantile scabies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of Circle of Hebra lesions :

 

  • Circle of Hebra refers to the characteristic distribution of scabies lesions around the umbilicus in a circular pattern. 
  • This is a recognized feature of scabies and helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option C. Norwegian scabies is the most severe form:

 

  • Norwegian scabies (also called crusted scabies) is indeed the most severe form of scabies. 
  • It is characterized by massive hyperinfestation with thousands to millions of mites, extensive scaling, crusting, and hyperkeratosis. 

 

 

It typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, the elderly, or those with neurological disorders.

 

Option D. Burrows are found in the stratum corneum:

 

  • The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite creates burrows specifically within the stratum corneum (the outermost layer of the epidermis). 
  • These burrows appear as thin, grayish, slightly raised, linear or curved lines and are pathognomonic for scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unlike in adults where the head and neck are typically spared, scabies in infants and young children commonly involves the scalp, face, and neck areas, making this an important distinguishing feature for diagnosing scabies in different age groups.

questions.text: Which form of cutaneous tuberculosis is typically contracted from direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis

 

  • Tuberculosis verrusosa cutis (TBVC) is the form of cutaneous tuberculosis that results from direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin of individuals with good immunity. 
  • It is also called "Anatomist's wart" or "Pathologist's wart" because of its occupational association. 
  • TVC presents as an indurated verrucous plaque that develops at the site of inoculation, typically on trauma-prone sites like the extremities. 

 

 

  • Due to the patient's good immunity, this is a paucibacillary form of cutaneous TB where the infection remains localized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is an endogenous form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs through contiguous spread from an underlying tuberculous focus (lymph node, bone, joint) to the overlying skin. 

 

 

  • It is not acquired through direct skin inoculation. 
  • Scrofuloderma is characterized by painless subcutaneous swellings that break down to form discharging sinuses with undermined edges.

 

Option B. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus Vulgaris can occur through both endogenous (hematogenous spread) and, less commonly, exogenous routes, but it typically affects individuals with moderate immunity rather than good immunity. 
  • It presents as a plaque with an active, advancing margin and central scarring. 

 

 

 

  • While it can occasionally be acquired through direct inoculation, it's not the typical presentation in individuals with good immunity, so TBVC is the better option to choose.

 

Option D. Any of the above:

 

  • Only Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is specifically associated with direct skin inoculation in individuals with good immunity.

 

Educational Objective:
