  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis is distinguished as the form of cutaneous TB acquired through exogenous inoculation in individuals with good immunity, presenting as a localized verrucous plaque at trauma-prone sites, particularly on the extremities.

questions.text: A patient with unilateral, unilocular suppurating bubo and a single sinus tract is observed to have a primary genital ulcer. The likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

  • Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers accompanied by unilateral suppurative (pus-filled) inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo). 

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen in chancroid.
  • The key connection here is the presence of both a primary genital ulcer and suppurating bubo with sinus tract formation. 
  • Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and has an incubation period of 3-5 days. 
  • The genital ulcer in chancroid is soft, tender, with necrotic base and ragged undermined edges that bleeds on touch. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum):

 

  • Incorrect because in LGV, the primary genital ulcer is transient and often goes unnoticed or has already healed by the time the bubo develops. 
  • The question explicitly mentions the presence of both the ulcer and bubo simultaneously, which is characteristic of chancroid rather than LGV.
  • LGV buboes also tend to exhibit the "groove sign" due to involvement of both inguinal and femoral nodes.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Genitalis:

 

  • Incorrect because while herpes causes painful genital ulcers (typically multiple grouped vesicles that rupture to form ulcers with polycyclic margins), it does not cause suppurative bubo formation with sinus tracts. 
  • Herpes may cause bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, but not the formation of buboes that suppurate.

 

Option D. Primary Syphilis:

 

  • Incorrect because primary syphilis causes a painless, indurated, clean-based ulcer (chancre) with non-suppurative bilateral lymphadenopathy. 
  • The lymph nodes in primary syphilis are typically described as "shotty" and do not form suppurative buboes or sinus tracts. 
  • The lymphadenopathy is also usually bilateral rather than unilateral.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The combination of a primary genital ulcer with a concurrent unilateral suppurating bubo that forms a sinus tract is highly characteristic of chancroid, distinguishing it from other sexually transmitted infections like LGV (where the primary lesion is often absent by the time buboes appear), herpes (which doesn't cause suppurative buboes), and syphilis (which causes painless, non-suppurating lymphadenopathy).

choices.text: May be confused with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome

questions.text: All of the following statements about Menetrier’s disease are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Usually increased acid secretion

 

Explanation:

 

Ménétrier's disease is characterized by decreased gastric acid secretion, not increased secretion. The disease features massive foveolar hyperplasia with marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells, which are responsible for acid production. Histologically, there is hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucous cells with a marked reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a premalignant condition: Ménétrier's disease is considered premalignant by some clinicians, though the exact risk of neoplastic progression is not well defined.

 

Option C. May be confused with Zollinger: Ellison Syndrome - Both conditions can present with similar symptoms including abdominal pain, though ZES has increased acid secretion while Ménétrier's has decreased acid secretion.

 

Option D. Associated with protein: losing enteropathy - Twenty to 100% of patients with Ménétrier's disease develop a protein-losing gastropathy due to hypersecretion of gastric mucus, accompanied by hypoalbuminemia and edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Ménétrier's disease is characterized by hypochlorhydria (decreased acid secretion) due to parietal cell loss, which distinguishes it from hypersecretory conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome despite potential overlap in clinical presentation.

questions.text: The diagnosis of a carcinoid tumor is done by urinary estimation of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 HIAA

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). When metabolized, serotonin produces 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in the urine. Neuroendocrine tumors like carcinoid are causes of secretory diarrhea, and specific diagnostic markers include elevated serum Chromogranin A (CgA) and urinary 5-HIAA.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid): VMA is a metabolite of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine). It is elevated in pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Option B. Metanephrines: These are also metabolites of catecholamines and are elevated in pheochromocytoma. They are not associated with carcinoid tumors.

 

Option C. Catecholamines: These are hormones including epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are elevated in conditions like pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma, not in carcinoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin, which when metabolized produces 5-HIAA that can be measured in urine as a diagnostic marker. Chromogranin A (CgA) is another important tumor marker for carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: Which brain region's lesion leads to prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-temporal

 

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, which results from lesions in the occipito-temporal cortex, specifically the fusiform face area. This region is specialized for facial recognition and processing. The right hemisphere's fusiform gyrus is particularly critical for this function. When damaged, patients can still see faces normally but cannot identify them as familiar - they may even fail to recognize their own face in a mirror, despite having intact visual perception of other objects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal lobe - Lesions here typically cause deficits like hemineglect (right parietal), Gerstmann syndrome (left angular gyrus with agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion), or constructional/dressing apraxia, not prosopagnosia.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe - Damage causes executive dysfunction, personality changes, motor deficits, and Broca's aphasia when in the dominant hemisphere. Face recognition remains intact.

 

Option D. Parieto-occipital - While this region is involved in complex visual processing, lesions here typically cause visual spatial deficits like Balint's syndrome rather than specific face recognition problems.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Prosopagnosia results from damage to specialized face-processing regions in the occipito-temporal cortex (fusiform face area), typically following right posterior cerebral artery territory infarcts.

questions.text: What is the root value associated with a normal plantar response?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S1

 

The plantar response (plantar reflex) is a superficial reflex that involves the integrity of the S1 nerve root. When the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is stimulated with a blunt object, the normal response (negative Babinski sign) is plantar flexion of the toes. This reflex is mediated by the S1 nerve root. The plantar reflex is an important part of the neurological examination, as an abnormal response (Babinski sign) indicates upper motor neuron pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: The L4 nerve root primarily mediates the patellar (knee) reflex, not the plantar response. L4 innervates the anterior thigh muscles and provides sensation to the medial leg.

 

Option B. L5: The L5 nerve root innervates the dorsiflexors of the foot and provides sensation to the lateral leg and dorsum of the foot, but is not the primary root for the plantar reflex.

 

Option D. S4: The S4 nerve root is involved in innervation of the perineum and contributes to bowel and bladder function, not the plantar response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal plantar response (plantar flexion of the toes) is mediated by the S1 nerve root, which is an important component of testing lower motor neuron integrity during neurological examination.

questions.text: Which of the following pairings is incorrectly matched? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D. Aromatase inhibitor - Triptorelin

 

Explanation:

 

Triptorelin is incorrectly matched as an aromatase inhibitor. Triptorelin is actually a GnRH agonist (Gonadotropin Releasing Hormone agonist) that, when administered continuously, leads to downregulation of pituitary GnRH receptors, resulting in suppression of FSH and LH release, and consequently decreasing testosterone and estrogen levels. Triptorelin is used in prostatic carcinoma, endometriosis, precocious puberty and uterine leiomyoma.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A. SERM - Raloxifene: This is a correct match. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator that selectively acts as an estrogen agonist in bone and on lipid metabolism, but as an antagonist in endometrium and breast. It is used for prevention and treatment of osteoporosis and reduces the risk of breast cancer.
  • B. SERD - Fulvestrant: This is a correct match. Fulvestrant is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Down-regulator. It inhibits ER dimerization so that ER interaction with DNA is prevented and receptor degradation is enhanced. It's used for locally advanced or metastatic ER positive breast cancer that has stopped responding to tamoxifen.
  • C. Herceptin - Trastuzumab: This is a correct match. Herceptin is the brand name for trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Triptorelin is a GnRH agonist used in prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty, while aromatase inhibitors (letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) act by blocking the conversion of androgens to estrogens, making them useful in postmenopausal breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is a fifth-generation cephalosporin active against MRSA? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Ceftaroline

 

Explanation:

 

Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin specifically designed to be active against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It differs from other cephalosporins by its ability to bind to the altered penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) expressed in MRSA, particularly PBP2a, which confers methicillin resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Ceftolozane - This is not a fifth-generation cephalosporin with anti-MRSA activity. Ceftolozane is typically combined with tazobactam and has activity primarily against gram-negative bacteria including Pseudomonas.
  • Option C. Cefpirome - Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin without specific activity against MRSA.
  • Option D. Ceftizoxime - This is a third-generation cephalosporin without activity against MRSA.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fifth-generation cephalosporins such as ceftaroline are distinguished by their ability to bind to altered PBPs in MRSA, making them effective against this resistant organism that is typically not susceptible to other β-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following biological agents for rheumatoid arthritis is a JAK inhibitor? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Tofacitinib

 

Explanation:

 

Tofacitinib is a synthetic non-biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that acts as a JAK (Janus kinase) inhibitor. It specifically inhibits JAK-3 and JAK-1 kinases, interfering with the JAK-STAT signaling pathway and DNA transcription. Tofacitinib inhibits the production of inflammatory mediators and cytokine release. It's classified among the conventional DMARDs as an inhibitor of JAK, along with baricitinib (which is also used in COVID-19).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Etanercept - This is a biological DMARD that works by inhibiting TNF-α (tumor necrosis factor alpha). It's administered through subcutaneous route and is categorized among the TNF-α inhibitors including Adalimumab, Certolizumab, Etanercept, Infliximab, and Golimumab.
  • Option B. Tocilizumab - This is a biological DMARD that acts as an IL-6 receptor antagonist. It was the first IL-6 targeted monoclonal antibody and is approved for treatment of cytokine release syndrome as well.
  • Option C. Abatacept - This is a biological DMARD classified as a co-stimulation inhibitor. It functions by inhibiting the interaction between T-cells and Antigen Presenting Cells (APC).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tofacitinib represents a distinct class of DMARDs that targets intracellular signaling via JAK inhibition, whereas biological DMARDs like etanercept, tocilizumab, and abatacept target specific extracellular cytokines or cell-surface interactions.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Aprepitant? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. NK1 receptor antagonist

 

Explanation: 

 

Aprepitant is a selective, high-affinity NK1 receptor antagonist that blocks the emetic action of substance P. It works by specifically binding to neurokinin-1 receptors in the central nervous system, particularly in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS). This mechanism is distinct from the more common 5-HT3 receptor antagonists used as antiemetics.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. RANK ligand inhibitor - This mechanism belongs to drugs affecting bone metabolism like denosumab, not to antiemetic medications.
  • Option B. NMDA antagonist - This mechanism relates to certain anesthetics and analgesics, not to aprepitant or other antiemetics.
  • Option D. 5-HT3 antagonist - While this is the mechanism for ondansetron, granisetron, and palonosetron, aprepitant specifically works through NK1 receptors with minimal effect on 5-HT3 receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Aprepitant's unique NK1 receptor antagonism makes it particularly valuable for preventing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting when combined with 5-HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone, providing superior control over the complete course of CINV.
